options.D: A reversion to the mechanical back-up mode.

key_points: A Fly-By-Wire (FBW) system uses computers to process the pilot's/autopilot's flight control inputs and send corresponding electrical signals to the flight control surfaces' actuators

Currently, it is generally accepted there are four levels of service employed within Fly-By-Wire systems; in descending order they are: Under Normal Control Law, normal operation, the computers ensure that flight manoeuvre envelope limits are not exceeded

Under Alternate Control Law, entered into after certain computer failures, the aircraft should handle almost exactly as in Normal control, but some protection features will be lost, including the possibility of losing autopilot function, dependent on the specific failures
learning.explanation: A Fly-By-Wire (FBW) system uses computers to process the pilot's/autopilot's flight control inputs and send corresponding electrical signals to the flight control surfaces' actuators. Currently, it is generally accepted there are four levels of service employed within Fly-By-Wire systems; in descending order they are: Under Normal Control Law, normal operation, the computers ensure that flight manoeuvre envelope limits are not exceeded. Under Alternate Control Law, entered into after certain computer failures, the aircraft should handle almost exactly as in Normal control, but some protection features will be lost, including the possibility of losing autopilot function, dependent on the specific failures. In Direct Control Law, all protections are lost and flying control input is translated directly into movement of the control surfaces without calculation or correction. The final degradation is Mechanical back-up. The aircraft is flown in pitch through use of the pitch trim wheel and roll by a mechanical connection retained to the rudder pedals (through the secondary effect of yaw). It is designed to allow the pilots to maintain control of the aircraft, while restoring flight control computers, after a complete power interruption. In the event of computer failure on a FBW aircraft, some form of back-up mode is required in the event of total computer failure. For this question, the statement "to the first level of degradation", means degradation to the "Alternate Law", where some protections may be lost.

content.question: Aeroplane manoeuvrability increases for a given control surface deflection when:

options.A: flaps are retracted at constant IAS.
options.B: the CG moves forward.
options.C: IAS decreases.
options.D: IAS increases.

key_points: When a control surface deflection takes place, the lift of an aerodynamic surface changes, generating more or less lift
This changes the moment from the aerodynamic surface acting on the aircraft, resulting in aircraft pitch, roll or yaw
The effectiveness of movement of these control surfaces increases with airspeed for a certain deflection
learning.explanation: When a control surface deflection takes place, the lift of an aerodynamic surface changes, generating more or less lift. This changes the moment from the aerodynamic surface acting on the aircraft, resulting in aircraft pitch, roll or yaw. The effectiveness of movement of these control surfaces increases with airspeed for a certain deflection. This happens because the deflection of the control surface changes the CL for the airfoil on which it operates. The effectiveness of surfaces operates through the lift formula (CL * ½ * ρ * V² * S). So, if CL increases, lift will also increase. In this question we are talking about a constant deflection, so CL will remain stable. Therefore, if we increase speed (v), lift will increase and so does the moment resulting from the control surface, increasing aeroplane manoeuvrability.

key_points: Control surfaces produce lift or drag
Lift and drag increase and decrease with increasing and decreasing speed
Therefore, only small deflections are necessary when flying with high airspeeds and larger deflections at lower speeds
learning.explanation: Control surfaces produce lift or drag. Lift and drag increase and decrease with increasing and decreasing speed. Therefore, only small deflections are necessary when flying with high airspeeds and larger deflections at lower speeds. The lift equation states: LIFT = ½ρV2SCL CL = coefficient of lift. This represents angle of attack of the airfoil and the shape of the airfoil. This described in terms of thickness/chord ratio and a camber and can be altered in flight, for example, by lowering the flaps. ρ = The density of the air. For any given altitude during subsonic flight, the density may be considered to be constant. V2 = The velocity of the aircraft, squared. S = The wing area. The lift formula can also be rearranged and written as: LIFT = q × S × CL (q = dynamic pressure, i.e. ½ρ × V2). In the lift equation all factors except density and speed (TAS) are constant. At higher altitude ρ is reduced; therefore TAS (V) must be increased to maintain the same lift (= weight). Drag equation states that: DRAG = ½ρV2SCD ρ = the mass density of the fluid (rho), V = the velocity of the object relative to the air, S = the reference area, CD = the drag coefficient - a dimensionless constant. The drag formula can be rearranged and written as: DRAG = CD × ½ρ × V2 × S From the drag equation it is clear that drag is directly proportional to the frontal area: if it increases by a factor of e.g. 3 the drag will be increased by the same factor.

In this scenario, the live engine generates a yawing moment on the dead engine, necessitating corrective action. The pivotal response involves applying rudder input to counteract the yaw induced by the engine failure. However, employing the rudder creates a sideslip, leading to increased drag. The offset rudder also generates a lateral force, exacerbating the sideslip. To mitigate these effects, banking (ailerons) towards the live engine is recommended. This banking maneuver reduces the required deflection of the rudder to maintain the desired track and minimize drag. It's crucial to note that a maximum banking angle of 5° towards the live engine is specified. This limitation is imposed to prevent larger bank angles, which could significantly diminish the vertical lift component.

This is known as the trimmable horizontal stabilizer (THS). The angle of incidence of an adjustable stabilizer is controlled by the airplane’s trim system, which alters the jack datum setting. The position of a properly trimmed variable-incidence tail plane depends, most importantly on, the CG position, the airspeed, the thrust setting and on the flap/slat position. When correctly trimmed the elevator angle relative to the horizontal stabilizer is neutral and the stabilized speed is referred to as the ‘trim speed.’ Thus, the trim may be used to set the desired speed without having to hold the elevator out of its trimmed position. A tail-heavy airplane would require the elevator to be deflected downward, which when the variable incidence tail plane is trimmed has no elevator deflection; it is in the neutral position and the leading edge of the adjustable stabilizer is up. key_points: During a bank, the upgoing wing effectively experiences a decreased angle of attack whilst the effective angle of attack of the down going wing increases
Consequently, the slope of the total lift vector generates a rearward component on the upgoing wing and a forward component on the down going wing
These are yaw moments but in the opposite direction to that of the roll caused by the difference of the induced drag of each wing
learning.explanation: During a bank, the upgoing wing effectively experiences a decreased angle of attack whilst the effective angle of attack of the down going wing increases. Consequently, the slope of the total lift vector generates a rearward component on the upgoing wing and a forward component on the down going wing. These are yaw moments but in the opposite direction to that of the roll caused by the difference of the induced drag of each wing. This is adverse yaw, which is particularly significant at low airspeeds because of the large aileron deflection necessary to achieve the same rate of roll as at higher speeds with less deflection. Adverse yaw may be counteracted by any one of the following devices: slot/aileron coupling. spoiler/aileron coupling. differential aileron deflection. rudder/aileron coupling. frise ailerons. To counteract adverse yaw the Frise ailerons are designed so that their leading edge produces sufficient profile drag on the upgoing aileron to equal the induced drag of the down going aileron and thus eliminate adverse yaw.

content.question: On a jet aeroplane (engines mounted below the low wing) the thrust is suddenly increased. Which of these statements is correct about the elevator deflection required to maintain zero pitching moment?

options.A: The amount of elevator deflection is independent of CG location.
options.B: The elevator must be deflected downward.
options.C: No elevator deflection be will required because the thrust line of the engines remains unchanged.
options.D: The elevator must be deflected upwards.

key_points: The vertical location of the thrust line defines one of the direct contributions to stability

If the thrust line is below the CG (the case of most airliners with underwing engines), a thrust increase will produce an added pitch-up moment => this will cause the airplane to slow down more than necessary (despite the added thrust)
Creating an unstable situation
learning.explanation: The vertical location of the thrust line defines one of the direct contributions to stability. If the thrust line is below the CG (the case of most airliners with underwing engines), a thrust increase will produce an added pitch-up moment => this will cause the airplane to slow down more than necessary (despite the added thrust). Creating an unstable situation. To counteract this, a pitch-down moment must be created. Therefore, the elevator must be deflected downwards. If the thrust line is above the CG, this is the opposite of the above and a thrust increase will produce a nose down moment (negative moment), and, in moderate amounts, can have a stabilising effect. The airplane will settle at a higher speed, which is presumably what the pilot wants (despite the "power controls altitude" mantra). When the line is too high, the airplane may even descend and accelerate more than necessary, until the aerodynamic moment balances out the thrust moment, but overall the condition is stable. Thrust is in line with CG. The airplane will start to climb (or reduce descent) and will settle on the same AoA and roughly the same speed.

key_points: The question is very simple but includes some sections outside of the syllabus, which we can mostly ignore, as they don't affect the answer
All aircraft have limitations to their speed and the loads that they can sustain at those speeds
In particular, we have to know about the load/speed diagram for CS-25 (large) aeroplanes
learning.explanation: The question is very simple but includes some sections outside of the syllabus, which we can mostly ignore, as they don't affect the answer. All aircraft have limitations to their speed and the loads that they can sustain at those speeds. In particular, we have to know about the load/speed diagram for CS-25 (large) aeroplanes. There is a diagram for the maximum load factors (positive and negative) that an aircraft can sustain, whether that limit was to do with a stall limit, or a structural load factor limit. There is also a limiting gust envelope diagram for the maximum gusts an aircraft must be able to handle at various speeds, see annex above. This creates some set design speeds for the aircraft, such as VA, VB, VC and VD. VA - Manoeuvring Speed, the speed where the aircraft will stall at exactly the limiting load factor (2.5 G for CS-25 aircraft). VB - Design Speed for Maximum Gust Intensity, the speed where an aircraft must be able to manage a gust of up to 66 fps. VC - Design Cruise Speed, the maximum speed an aircraft is able to cruise at, giving sufficient safety margin to VD, and means the aircraft will not exceed VD if a particular disturbance occurs when cruising at VC. It is also the point where gusts of up to 50 fps should be managed by the airframe. VC should not be more than 0.8 x VD. VD - Design Dive Speed, the maximum speed that the aircraft can handle in a dive, often limited by vibrations, buffet or flutter. This is the absolute speed limit of the airframe, and the aircraft should be able to manage 25 fps gusts at this speed. There is also a flight demonstrated design dive speed (VDF) which is a demonstrated speed that the aircraft can handle without associated vibrations, buffet or flutter. It is different from VD but for the purposes of this question we do not need to know any more about it. To keep the aircraft within safe operation, the VMO (maximum operating speed) must be kept below VC. This is still very fast, and should not be exceeded in normal operations. This means that it is always sufficiently less than from VD/MD and VDF/MDF. CS 25.1505 Maximum operating limit speed The maximum operating limit speed (VMO/MMO, airspeed or Mach number, whichever is critical at a particular altitude) is a speed that may not be deliberately exceeded in any regime of flight (climb, cruise, or descent), unless a higher speed is authorised for flight test or pilot training operations. VMO/MMO must be established so that it is not greater than the design cruising speed VC and so that it is sufficiently below VD/MD or VDF/MDF, to make it highly improbable that the latter speeds will be inadvertently exceeded in operations. The speed margin between VMO/MMO and VD/MD or VDF/MDF may not be less than that determined under CS 25.335(b) or found necessary during the flight tests conducted under CS 25.253.

learning.explanation: An aircraft has a limit load factor, which is the rated limit for the maximum G-force the aircraft can pull. It is primarily a structural consideration, and aircraft must be designed to exceed a certain load factor (dependent on the aircraft type) by 50% when new. For CS-25 (large transport aircraft) specifications, the flaps up positive limit load factor is 2.5G, and therefore each aircraft is tested to withstand 150% of this (3.75G) without complete structural failure for the initial aircraft certification. The limit load factor is based on the aircraft's maximum take-off weight (MTOW), and so an aircraft lighter than this would likely be able to withstand greater than this load factor before permanent damage occurs (due to the lower forces on the structure), but this is not allowed, and the limit load factor does NOT change with weight, and should never be exceeded under normal operations.

In theory, the lighter aircraft could withstand more "g" before the stress reached the same level as during takeoff. Which of these statements about the gust load factor on an aeroplane are correct or incorrect?
I. When the slope of the lift versus angle of attack curve increases, the gust load factor decreases.
II. When the wing loading increases, the gust load factor increases.

options.A: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.B: I is correct, II is correct.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.D: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.

key_points: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical
The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor
The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor
learning.explanation: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical. The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor. The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor. The gust load is the extra load imparted to the airplane by vertical gusts or turbulence. Its magnitude is unaffected by increased altitude but is increased with increased aspect ratio and/or decreased mass. The load factor for any given angle of attack can be derived from the basic load factor for the normal cruise angle of attack because it is increased by the same percentage as the increase of angle of attack. The load factor deriving from a gust is determined by the magnitude of the vertical velocity of the gust and the forward speed of the airplane. Vertical gusts will affect the load factor (n) by changing the angle of attack of the wing. For a given gust speed and aircraft TAS, the increment in the load factor depends on the increase in CL per change in angle of attack due to the gust (the slope of the lift curve). If the lift curve has a steep slope, the ‘g’ increment will be greater. Factors which affect the lift curve are aspect ratio and wing sweep. Wings having a low aspect ratio, or sweep, will have a lower lift curve slope, and so will give a smaller increase in ‘g’ when meeting a given gust at a given TAS. Therefore, statement 1 is incorrect. High wing loading reduces the ‘g’ increment in a gust. This is because the lift increment produced is a smaller proportion of the original lift force for the more heavily loaded aircraft. For a given TAS and gust speed, the increase of lift will be proportional to the wing area. Therefore, the increase in load factor is inversely proportional to the wing loading. Wing Loading = Weight/(Wing Area) Therefore, statement 2 is incorrect.

Also, we think the examiner is very misleading to include "VD" as an option, as it is certainly correct (VNE is always less than VD), but is less specific than "0.9 x VD", making it tough to decide between "less specific but absolutely correct" and "more specific but more complex to justify" answers. Please keep on sending any exam feedback you have, and we will keep these questions as up to date as we can for you, thanks! Each type of aircraft has its own specific flight envelope, within which it can be safely operated in accordance with the EASA Certification Specifications. This is represented on a velocity against load factor, or V-n diagram. The high-speed limit for many (but not all) CS-23 aircraft is the never exceed speed (VNE) and is a design reference point for the aircraft beyond which the aircraft must not be flown. It provides a safety margin with the point at which structural damage or failure may occur(VD). VNE is the red radial line at the high speed end of the airspeed indicator. Never Exceed Speed VNE: VNE is set below VD to allow for speed upsets to be recovered before reaching any point of possible damage. VNE equals 0.9 x VD in most cases, but please see the regulation for this below, as there is some "wiggle room" in the regulation that makes things slightly more complex (hence our unhappiness with these options). CS 23.1505 - Airspeed Limitations (a) The never-exceed speed VNE must be established so that it is – (1) Not less than 0.9 times the minimum value of VD allowed under CS 23.335; and (2) Not more than the lesser of – (i) 0.9 VD established under CS 23.335; or (ii) 0.9 times the maximum speed shown under CS 23.251.

content.question: An aircraft is flying in steady, straight and level flight with a Coefficient of Lift of 0.47. Calculate the final load factor if a vertical gust increases the angle of attack by 3°. Consider that a change in 1° of Angle of Attack produces a change in CL of 0.1.

key_points: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical
The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor
The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor
learning.explanation: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical. The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor. The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor. The gust load is the extra load imparted to the airplane by vertical gusts or turbulence. Its magnitude is unaffected by increased altitude but is increased with increased aspect ratio and/or decreased mass. The load factor for any given angle of attack can be derived from the basic load factor for the normal cruise angle of attack because it is increased by the same percentage as the increase of angle of attack. It can be defined by: load factor(n) = (Lift(L)) / (Weight(W)) In straight and level flight, Lift = Weight, thus n = 1. In this exercise, the increment in CL from a gust will be of 0.1 for every degree of angle of attack impacted by the gust. We also know that the aircraft encounters a gust which increases its angle of attack by 3°. In straight and level flight n = 1 or : n = 0.47 / 0.47 A 3° increase in angle of attack, 3 * 0.1 = 0.3 Will give an increment of 0.3 in the CL : 0.47+0.3 = 0.77 A gust which increases the angle of attack by 3° will increase the load factor to : n = 0.77 / 0.47 ≈ 1.64g

content.question:
Which of the following statements is correct?
I. A higher limit load factor allows the manufacturer to design for a lower stick force per g.
II. The stick force per g is a limitation on aeroplane's operation, which the pilot can determine from the Aeroplane Flight Manual.

options.A: I. is correct, II. is incorrect.
options.B: I. is correct, II. is correct.
options.C: I. is incorrect, II. is incorrect.
options.D: I. is incorrect, II. is correct.

key_points: MANOEUVRING STABILITY Whenever an aircraft is manoeuvring, acceleration forces act on it (if, for example, the aircraft is pulling out of a dive, its flight path will be curved and the resultant pitching velocity provides aerodynamic damping in pitch due to the downward movement of the tailplane)
The tailplane provides the largest contribution toward damping in pitch, although other aircraft components such as the wings do assist
A graph of stick force versus load factor illustrates the manoeuvring stability of an aircraft
learning.explanation: MANOEUVRING STABILITY Whenever an aircraft is manoeuvring, acceleration forces act on it (if, for example, the aircraft is pulling out of a dive, its flight path will be curved and the resultant pitching velocity provides aerodynamic damping in pitch due to the downward movement of the tailplane). The tailplane provides the largest contribution toward damping in pitch, although other aircraft components such as the wings do assist. A graph of stick force versus load factor illustrates the manoeuvring stability of an aircraft. The gradient of the graph should be positive (with increasing load factor the stick force must also increase). This gradient must not be excessively high or the aircraft would be difficult and tiring to manoeuvre. Conversely, it should not be too low or the stick forces would be too light and the aircraft could be over-stressed. The maximum load factors which must be allowed for during maneuvers are shown in an envelope of load factor against speed (EAS). If a higher limit load factor is set by the manufacturer, there's more margin for the aircraft to be controlled inside the envelope and therefore a lower stick force per g may be set. Statement I is correct. The limit load factors will depend on the design category of the aircraft. For example, the limit load factor for modern high-speed jet transport aircraft is -1.0 g and 2.5 g. This value is stated in the Aircraft Flight Manual to be consulted by the pilot and should bever be exceeded. However, the stick force per g is not listed in the AFM. Statement II is incorrect.

key_points: LANDING GEAR SPEED LIMITATIONS The landing gear will normally be retracted as soon as possible after take-off to reduce drag and increase the climb gradient
There is no normal requirement for the gear to be operated at high IAS so the retract and extend mechanism together with the attachment points to the structure are sized for the required task
LANDING GEAR EXTENDED SPEED - VLE There may be occasions when it is necessary to ferry the aircraft with the gear down, and to do this a higher permissible speed would be convenient
learning.explanation: LANDING GEAR SPEED LIMITATIONS The landing gear will normally be retracted as soon as possible after take-off to reduce drag and increase the climb gradient. There is no normal requirement for the gear to be operated at high IAS so the retract and extend mechanism together with the attachment points to the structure are sized for the required task. LANDING GEAR EXTENDED SPEED - VLE There may be occasions when it is necessary to ferry the aircraft with the gear down, and to do this a higher permissible speed would be convenient. VLE is the speed at which it is safe to fly the aircraft with the landing gear secured in the fully extended position. LANDING GEAR OPERATING SPEED - VLO This is the speed at which it is safe both to extend and to retract the landing gear. If the extension speed is not the same as the retraction speed, the two speeds must be designated as VLO (EXT) and VLO (RET). When the gear is retracted or extended the doors must open first. The doors merely streamline the undercarriage bay and are not designed to take the aerodynamic loads which would be placed on them at high IAS. Consequently VLO is usually lower than VLE.

content.question: An aircraft certified under CS-23 has a VA of 181 kt at a mass of 5.7 t. The value of VA at a mass of 5.5 t is…

options.A: 130 kt
options.B: 178 kt
options.C: 154 kt
options.D: 252 kt

key_points: Maneuvering Speed (VA) is the speed at which an airplane will stall before exceeding its maximum load limit
To calculate the VA we multiply the stall speed (VS1) by the square root of the load factor (n)
VA = VS1 x √n VA is just a stalling speed
learning.explanation: Maneuvering Speed (VA) is the speed at which an airplane will stall before exceeding its maximum load limit. To calculate the VA we multiply the stall speed (VS1) by the square root of the load factor (n). VA = VS1 x √n VA is just a stalling speed. Thus, it varies with mass: New VS = Old VS x √Change in mass factor New VA = 181 x √ (5500 / 5700) New VA = 181 x 0.9823 New VA = approx. 178 kt

content.question: For a given gust velocity, by how much would the gust load increase for an aircraft flying at 40000 ft, compared to the same aircraft flying at sea level, if the EAS remains the same? The gust load would increase by...

options.A: zero, there will be no increase at all.
options.B: twice as much.
options.C: half as much.
options.D: a quarter.

key_points: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical
In a vertical gust the change in angle of attack is proportional to the ratio of TAS/vertical gust velocity
True Airspeed: The speed of the aircraft through the air
learning.explanation: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical. In a vertical gust the change in angle of attack is proportional to the ratio of TAS/vertical gust velocity. True Airspeed: The speed of the aircraft through the air. TAS = EAS / √σ where, σ is Relative Density. The Airspeed Indicator is calibrated for ‘standard’ sea level density, so it will only read TAS if the density of the air through which the aircraft is flying is 1.225 kg/m3. Thus at 40 000 ft where the ‘standard’ density is one quarter of the sea-level value, to maintain the same EAS the aircraft will have to move through the air twice as fast. As altitude increases the TAS at any given CAS increases, so the effect of a vertical gust decreases. At 40 000 ft ISA for example, the TAS at constant EAS is about twice its sea level value. The upgust will change the direction of the relative undisturbed airflow approaching the wing by roughly half as much.

content.question: An aeroplane maintains straight and level flight at a speed of 1.8 VS. A vertical gust causes a load factor of 1.9. Determine the load factor n caused by the same gust at a speed of 2VS:

options.D: Not relevant. The gust at 1.8 VS would cause a stall.

key_points: An aircraft travelling at a certain speed (Vold) encounters a vertical gust which increases its load factor (nold) to a certain amount
The goal is to compare the effect of the same gust on an aircraft travelling at a different speed (Vnew, in blue) and assessing the resultant load factor (nnew)
Vold = 1
learning.explanation: An aircraft travelling at a certain speed (Vold) encounters a vertical gust which increases its load factor (nold) to a certain amount. The goal is to compare the effect of the same gust on an aircraft travelling at a different speed (Vnew, in blue) and assessing the resultant load factor (nnew). Vold = 1.8VS nold = 1.9g Vnew = 2VS nnew =? The first thing we should do is check if in the first situation the aircraft is stalled, by comparing the two VS0: VS1 = VS0 x √(nold) VS1 = √1.9 x VS0 = 1.38VS0 1.38VS0 < 1.8VS0 Therefore, the aircraft is not stalled! As the aircraft does not stall in the first situation, we can calculate the load factor resulting from the same gust on an aircraft travelling at Vnew using a direct proportion: Vold x (nnew−1) = Vnew x (nold−1) nnew = ((Vnew x (nold−1)) / Vold) +1 nnew = ((2VS x (1.9−1)) / 1.8VS) +1 nnew = 2.00g Encountering the same gust with a speed of 2VS the load factor will be 2.00g. The last step of the exercise is to assess the limiting load factor at which the aircraft would stall and conclude if the new load factor calculated would be reached or the aircraft would stall before that. To do this, let us compare Vnew with the stall speed (VS) and load factor in straight and level flight (n1g): Vnew = VS * √(n1g From here results that our limiting load factor is: n1g = V2new n1g = 4.00g As our limiting load factor is higher than the new. In this case encountering the gust the aircraft would have its load factor increased to 2.00g without stalling.

content.question: For a given gust speed and aircraft TAS, what is the impact of the lift curve’s slope on the gust load factor?

options.A: The steeper the lift curve’s slope, the greater the gust load factor.
options.B: The steeper the lift curve’s slope, the smaller the gust load factor.
options.C: The lift curve’s slope has no impact on the gust load factor.
options.D: The shallower the lift curve’s slope, the greater the gust load factor.

key_points: Vertical gusts will affect the load factor (n) by changing the angle of attack of the wing

learning.explanation: Vertical gusts will affect the load factor (n) by changing the angle of attack of the wing. For a given gust speed and aircraft TAS, the increment in the load factor depends on the increase in CL per change in angle of attack due to the gust (the slope of the lift curve). If the lift curve has a steep slope, the ‘g’ increment will be greater. Factors which affect the lift curve are aspect ratio and wing sweep. Wings having a low aspect ratio, or sweep, will have a lower lift curve slope, and so will give a smaller increase in ‘g’ when meeting a given gust at a given TAS.

We have had to choose some figures to fit an answer, which are unlikely to be the same in the exam! Please send us any further exam feedback you can remember if you get this in your exam, so we can make it more exact, thank you! An aircraft has a limit load factor, that signifies the maximum G-force that the aircraft can handle, before potential damage may occur to the airframe
VA is an aircraft's manoeuvring speed, and exists where the aircraft can handle exactly its limit load factor before stalling
learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: This is created from quite old feedback, and the figures are not known/confirmed. We have had to choose some figures to fit an answer, which are unlikely to be the same in the exam! Please send us any further exam feedback you can remember if you get this in your exam, so we can make it more exact, thank you! An aircraft has a limit load factor, that signifies the maximum G-force that the aircraft can handle, before potential damage may occur to the airframe. VA is an aircraft's manoeuvring speed, and exists where the aircraft can handle exactly its limit load factor before stalling. If the aircraft is flying slower than VA, then it will stall before reaching the limit load factor, and if it flying above VA, the limit load factor can be exceeded before stalling. We can therefore use VA in calculations, as it is the stall speed of an aircraft at it's limit load factor. Stall speed calculations are based on the lift force required by the wings, and that varies with weight and load factor (G-force). The higher the weight, or the higher the load factor, the higher airspeed that is required (more airflow makes the wing able to produce greater forces before stalling). For load factor, the formula is: New VS = VS(1G) x sqrt(load factor) Where VS(1G) is the stall speed at 1G (straight level flight) So for the manoeuvring speed VA = VS(1G) x sqrt(limit load factor) We can then re-arrange this to find the limit load factor if we know the VA and the VS(1G) (which we do in this question). The VS(1G) is given in the question as the bottom of the green arc. (VA / VS(1G))2 = limit load factor Limit load factor = (147/73)2 = 4.06 G

learning.explanation: THE FLIGHT OPERATING ENVELOPE Each type of aircraft has its own specific flight envelope, within which it can be safely operated in accordance with the EASA Certification Specifications. This is represented on a velocity against load factor, or V-n diagram. The V-n diagram illustrates the limit load factors and limit speeds that, if exceeded, may result in permanent structural damage. The limit loads vary depending on aircraft type, but for transport category aircraft these are generally +2.5g and -1g. At low airspeeds the stall may occur before reaching the limit load factor, but at high airspeeds the limit load factor may be reached before the stall. Gusts also affect the load factor, and the additional acceleration forces (g forces) associated with turbulence can result in structural damage (e.g. an up-gust at high airspeeds). Important reference speeds the pilot should be aware of are VS - Unaccelerated stall speed in the clean configuration VA - Maximum design manoeuvring speed and is the highest speed where the aircraft will stall before it exceeds the maximum load factor

A flight instructor is demonstrating stall and stall recovery during a lesson. As a part of the exercise, the instructor demonstrates the use of excessive pitch-down stick input during the initial portion of the recovery. Recovering from the dive, the pilot applies excessive back force on the stick, which forces the aeroplane to enter a secondary (accelerated) stall. Considering the aeroplane limitations given below, what speed range should the aeroplane be operated in order to safely carry out this demonstration?
VS: 45 kt
VA: 100 kt

key_points: COLOUR CODING OF THE ASI White arc This arc extends from VSO (stall full flap) to VFE (maximum speed with flaps extended), and marks the flap operating speed range
Green arc This arc extends from VSI (stall clean) to VNO (normal operating speed), and is the normal operating speed range
Yellow This arc extends from VNO to VNE (never exceed speed), and denotes the cautionary speed range
learning.explanation: COLOUR CODING OF THE ASI White arc This arc extends from VSO (stall full flap) to VFE (maximum speed with flaps extended), and marks the flap operating speed range. Green arc This arc extends from VSI (stall clean) to VNO (normal operating speed), and is the normal operating speed range. Yellow This arc extends from VNO to VNE (never exceed speed), and denotes the cautionary speed range. Operations within this speed range should not be carried out except in smooth air. Red Radial line This line marks VNE. MANOEUVERING SPEED (VA) (figure 2) VA - Maximum design manoeuvring speed and is the highest speed where the aircraft will stall before it exceeds the maximum load factor THE STALL The CL of an aerofoil increases with angle of attack up to a maximum (CLMAX). Any further increase above this stalling angle, or critical angle of attack, will make it impossible for the airflow to smoothly follow the upper wing contour, and the flow will separate from the surface, causing CL to decrease and drag to increase rapidly. A stall is caused by airflow separation. Separation can occur when either the boundary layer has insufficient kinetic energy or the adverse pressure gradient becomes too great. STALL RECOVERY To recover from a stall or prevent a full stall, the angle of attack must be decreased to reduce the adverse pressure gradient. This may consist of merely releasing back pressure, or it may be necessary to smoothly move the pitch control forward, depending on the aircraft design and severity of the stall. Allow airspeed to increase and recover lost altitude with moderate back pressure on the pitch control. Pulling too hard could trigger a secondary stall, or worse, could exceed the limit load factor and damage the aircraft structure. At low airspeeds the stall may occur before reaching the limit load factor. That is why, when pulling from a stall recovery, keeping the speed between VS and VA will allow us to not stall again due to the increased load factor. As angle of attack reduces below the critical angle, the adverse pressure gradient will decrease, airflow will re-attach, and lift and drag will return to their normal values.

learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.06.01.03.03: Define ‘VFE’ and describe flap limiting speeds. VFE is the maximum speed to be flown with flaps extended. Flaps are incredibly useful for aircraft to allow for slower take-off and landing, as well as increasing drag for increased control during descent and approach phases of flight, and changing the landing pitch attitude of some aircraft. They do have to sustain some very high aerodynamic loads though, as they stick out into the airstream below the wing, and produce very high forces of lift and drag. The maximum speed for flaps extended (VFE) therefore exists to make sure the pilots do not fly too fast with flaps extended, and cause damage to the flaps or their mechanisms. Some large aircraft actually have systems to reduce the flap extension when these speed limits are broken. In this question then, during the approach phase of flight, the pilots will be wanting to extend flaps in preparation for landing, but if the speed is too high and the pilots extend flaps anyway, they may exceed the new (lower) VFE for the increased flap setting. As for the other options: VLO is the maximum speed for landing gear operation (it is often specified whether that is for extension or retraction) VMO is the maximum operating IAS for the aircraft. com, thank you! Aircraft can be certified under 2 different certification specifications; CS-23 or CS-25
learning.explanation: Note: You may see this question with VMO or MMO used interchangeably, either can be used, it does not change the answer. Please let us know which you get in the exam, by placing feedback in the comments or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! Aircraft can be certified under 2 different certification specifications; CS-23 or CS-25. CS-23 covers "small aircraft". This includes aircraft with MTOW of 5670 kg or less and a maximum operational passenger seating configuration (MOPSC) of 9 or fewer. CS-23 also covers commuter category aircraft up to 8618 kg MTOW and a MOPSC of 19 or fewer. This means that there are CS-23 aircraft with an MTOW above 5670 kg. CS-25 covers "large aircraft". Specifically, "turbine powered Large Aeroplanes". This includes turboprop aircraft as well as turbojet/turbofan (jet aircraft). There is a difference between the limiting flight airspeeds, VNE and VMO/MMO. Some aircraft (usually smaller, slower aircraft) use VNE - the never exceed speed, and a corresponding VNO, the normal operating speed, which should only be exceeded in smooth air (bottom of the yellow arc). Larger/faster aircraft use VMO/MMO - the maximum operating speed/maximum operating Mach number. This is calculated a little differently to VNE, and is a speed that should not be exceeded during normal operations. An aircraft either has VNE or VMO/MMO, never both. If an aircraft uses VMO, it will also have a corresponding MMO, but this is not mentioned in this question CS-23 aircraft mostly use VNE, but turbine powered aeroplanes and those with a particular design dive speed instead use a VMO/MMO (CS 23.1505). Therefore, CS-23 aircraft can use either VNE or VMO/MMO, depending on the particular aircraft. CS-25 aircraft only use VMO/MMO. Now we have enough information to go through each option: "Only jet aeroplanes have a VMO." No, there are turboprop aircraft within CS-25 (and CS-23) that also have VMO, and even the possibility for piston aircraft to have VMO under CS-23 in some cases (CS 23.1505). "VNE applies to all aircraft with an MTOW less than 5 670 kg." No, there are aircraft under 5 670 kg with more than 9 passenger seats that would be under CS-25 (and therefore have a VMO) and there are also aircraft within CS-23 that use VMO (CS 23.1505). "VNE only applies to CS-23 aircraft but NOT to CS-25 aircraft." Yes, the majority of CS-23 aircraft use a VNE (but not all), and CS-25 aircraft only use VMO, so do not use VNE at all. "VMO only applies to CS-25 aircraft but NOT to CS-23 aircraft." No. Whilst all CS-25 aircraft do use a VMO, so do some aircraft certified under CS-23 (turbines and certain piston aircraft [CS 23.1505])

learning.explanation: All aircraft have limitations to their speed and the loads that they can sustain at those speeds. In particular, we have to know about the load/speed diagram for CS-25 (large) aeroplanes. There is a diagram for the maximum load factors (positive and negative) that an aircraft can sustain, whether that limit was to do with a stall limit, or a structural load factor limit. There is also a limiting gust envelope diagram for the maximum gusts an aircraft must be able to handle at various speeds, see annex above. This creates some set design speeds for the aircraft, such as VA, VB, VC and VD. VA - Manoeuvring Speed, the speed where the aircraft will stall at exactly the limiting load factor (2.5 G for CS-25 aircraft). VB - Design Speed for Maximum Gust Intensity, the speed where an aircraft must be able to manage a gust of up to 66 fps. VC - Design Cruise Speed, the maximum speed an aircraft is able to cruise at, giving sufficient safety margin to VD, and means the aircraft will not exceed VD if a particular disturbance occurs when cruising at VC. It is also the point where gusts of up to 50 fps should be managed by the airframe. VC should not be more than 0.8 x VD. VD - Design Dive Speed, the maximum speed that the aircraft can handle in a dive, often limited by vibrations, buffet or flutter. This is the absolute speed limit of the airframe, and the aircraft should be able to manage 25 fps gusts at this speed.

key_points: Flutter is a phenomenon that can occur when an airfoil is subjected to aerodynamic forces

Flutter happens when the eigenfrequencies of two oscillations move close together so their motions can reinforce themselves mutually
learning.explanation: Flutter is a phenomenon that can occur when an airfoil is subjected to aerodynamic forces. Flutter is an oscillation caused by interaction of aerodynamic forces, structural elasticity and inertial effects. Flutter happens when the eigenfrequencies of two oscillations move close together so their motions can reinforce themselves mutually. When that happens, then the amplitude will increase with each oscillation, up to a point where the amplitude is big enough to break things. Flutter is a very dangerous condition; if it is not stopped, it can cause structural failure and potentially lead to a fatal accident. There are four ways to stop flutter. Limit the flight envelope; immediately leave the speed at which flutter is possible Increase damping; this can be done by for instance adding some friction Increase stiffness; this reduces eigenfrequencies which makes flutter less likely Reduce mass; If a wing is made lighter, the eigenfrequency will move up, increasing flutter speeds.

learning.explanation: VS1 is the stalling speed of an aircraft in 1g level flight, with flaps retracted. VSO is the stalling speed in the landing configuration, and therefore not relevant. VA is the design manoeuvring speed at which the aircraft will stall when achieving its maximum load factor, i.e. it is the stalling speed of an aircraft at its Limit Load Factor ("g" limit) with flaps retracted. On an aircraft, where only one VA is published, maximum mass is assumed. In practice, like any stalling speed, VA will change during flight, decreasing as fuel is burnt and mass reduces. The significance of VA is that below this speed, the pilot can apply full elevator deflection and the aircraft will stall before reaching its "g" limit. But above VA, it becomes possible to exceed the "g" limit and there is risk of overstressing and deforming the airframe. For an aerobatic aircraft, the "g" limit is 6g. For this question, VA is given by the stall speed formula with flaps retracted: VA = VS1 x √(Limit Load Factor) = 57 x √6 = 140 kt. content.question: Which of the following statements best describes VA?

options.A: The speed for maximum gust velocity.
options.B: A specifically designated speed to use when penetrating turbulence.
options.C: A speed chosen by the manufacturer for evaluating performance criteria.
options.D: The design manoeuvring speed, at or near which rapid, full control reversal should be avoided due to risk of damage to aircraft.

key_points: VA is the design manoeuvring speed of an aircraft
It is better depicted on a diagram of speed vs load factor (V - n diagram)
The aircraft has a limiting load factor, an amount of acceleration that it can take without permanently damaging the airframe
learning.explanation: VA is the design manoeuvring speed of an aircraft. It is better depicted on a diagram of speed vs load factor (V - n diagram). The aircraft has a limiting load factor, an amount of acceleration that it can take without permanently damaging the airframe. Every aircraft also has a stalling curve, which dictates at what speed the aircraft will stall, when pulling a certain load factor. Put these two together on a diagram and you can see the V - n envelope of the aircraft, how fast we can fly and how many Gs we can pull at a particular speed. VA sits around where the positive stall curve touches the limit load factor. It dictates the point where you can pull the controls as hard as you want, and just as you reach the limit load factor (structural damage point), the aircraft will then stall, removing the chance of structural damage. Any slower and you will stall first, and any faster, and you could permanently damage the airframe. It is not always perfectly on that corner of the diagram, but that is past the scope of this question To look at all the options "The speed for maximum gust velocity." No. The speed for maximum gust velocity is VB, and occurs just above the VA. It is the speed that the aircraft is certified to handle the highest level of gusts (66 fps). "A specifically designated speed to use when penetrating turbulence." The turbulence penetration speed is actually VB also, where the strongest gusts can be handled by the aircraft without stalling or damage occurring. "A speed chosen by the manufacturer for evaluating performance criteria." There are many different speed to evaluate performance criteria with, but they would never use VA, as it is not usually anywhere near speeds such as best range, minimum drag, etc. "The design manoeuvring speed, at or near which rapid, full control reversal should be avoided due to risk of damage to aircraft." Whilst the wording is (intentionally) poor for this option, it is the only one left. We believe that the "control reversal" would just mean going from one full deflection to the other side full deflection. That is really not advisable at any speed, but at and above VA would cause damage to the aircraft. Even just below VA, full control deflection from no deflection is fine (though you may stall), but reversal is not accounted for in the regulations, so in reality the examiner can say what they like to try and confuse you. This is the only remaining option, and correctly stated that it is the design manoeuvring speed, so we are happy to agree that it is most correct.

content.question: CS23 and CS25 specify the requirements for an aircraft's design manoeuvring speed (VA). Given that VA is an equivalent airspeed (EAS), it remains relevant for aeroplanes with conventional flight controls, however its value may become unreliable at high altitudes as…

options.B: higher stall speed and low control forces make it easier to produce a high load factor at high altitudes.

key_points: Learning Objective 081
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.06.02.02.03: Explain why VA loses significance at higher altitude. Manoeuvring speed (VA) is defined as the calibrated airspeed (CAS) below which the aircraft will stall before the onset of structural damage or aerodynamic buffeting occurs. It is a function of the aircraft's weight, altitude, and the configuration of the aircraft (flap and landing gear positions). VA is calculated based on EAS, which is the airspeed corrected for instrument and position errors. When jet transports cruise at high altitude, the significance of manoeuvring speed (VA) diminishes since it is not possible to achieve 2.5 g, or similar load factors, at high altitude. Consequently, when a single VA is published, it only applies to low-level flight. As altitude increases, the values of equivalent airspeed (EAS) that correspond to the same Mach numbers increase. The increase in Mach number results in a reduction in CLMAX, and the stall limit curves become shallower, causing both VS1 and VA to occur at higher EAS values. The increased stall speed (VS) means that the low altitude VA is around the low-speed stall at high altitude. Therefore, the option "higher stall speed and low control forces make it easier to produce a high load factor at high altitudes." is more likely correct, as flying the low altitude VA at high altitudes may result in a low-speed stall of a typical jet aircraft rather than a shock stall. content.question: Control surface flutter can be eliminated by:

options.A: reducing structural stiffness of the control surface attachment structure.
options.B: mass balancing of the control surface.
options.C: increasing airspeed.
options.D: aerodynamic balancing of the control surface.

key_points: Flutter is an oscillation of the control surface which can occur due to the bending and twisting of the structure under load
If the control surface CG is behind the hinge line, inertia will cause the surface to oscillate about its hinge line
The oscillations can be divergent and cause structural failure
learning.explanation: Flutter is an oscillation of the control surface which can occur due to the bending and twisting of the structure under load. If the control surface CG is behind the hinge line, inertia will cause the surface to oscillate about its hinge line. The oscillations can be divergent and cause structural failure. Flutter involves: - aerodynamic forces. - inertia forces. - the elastic properties of a surface. An aircraft is subject to many aerodynamic excitations (gusts, control inputs, etc.) and the aerodynamic forces at various speeds have characteristic properties for rate of change of force and moment. The interaction of the aerofoil mass and the aerodynamic load imposed on the aerofoil causes distortion by bending and torsion of the structure that can result in a violent vibration in the resonance frequency, which if excessive can cause structural failure. This is ‘flutter’ and the aeroelastic coupling will affect its characteristics. The risk of experiencing flutter increases with IAS. CONTROL SURFACE FLUTTER Control surface flutter can develop as a result of an oscillation of the control surface coupled with an oscillation in bending or twisting of the wing, tailplane or fin. A control surface oscillation can result from backlash (free play) in the control system or from a disturbance (gust). MASS BALANCE Flutter may be prevented by adding weight to the control surface in front of the hinge line. This brings the centre of gravity of the control forward to a position on, or slightly in front of the hinge, but always to the point required by the designers. This reduces the inertia moments about the hinge and prevents flutter developing.

content.question: A light aircraft with mechanical flight controls occasionally experiences uncomfortable pitch oscillations after encountering normal turbulence. The pilot does not note any such oscillations when cruising in smooth air at normal cruising speed, but does notice some excessive slack or play in the elevator linkages after the flight. What potential hazards could this situation cause if not addressed by maintenance?

options.A: This phugoid-type oscillation is likely to increase in magnitude and the aeroplane may enter a stall or encounter an overspeed situation if the oscillation worsens.
options.B: A poorly balanced control surface is creating excessive restoring forces and this short-period motion may cause excessive stress on the airframe.
options.C: The flutter may gradually worsen, and the elevator may vibrate so vigorously that it comes off the hinges and separates from the aeroplane in flight.
options.D: Compared to a phugoid, the short period motion leads to a change in pitch and speed, which, if NOT corrected, may lead to a stall or overspeed situation.

key_points: NOTE: We have had conflicting feedback about this question
The current answer is the one we believe to be most correct, but we are seeing some possible different answers with different authorities
We are in need of more feedback about this one, so please send us anything you can remember from the exam via the comments, the feedback section of the website, or by email to info@atplquestions
learning.explanation: NOTE: We have had conflicting feedback about this question. The current answer is the one we believe to be most correct, but we are seeing some possible different answers with different authorities. We are in need of more feedback about this one, so please send us anything you can remember from the exam via the comments, the feedback section of the website, or by email to info@atplquestions.com, thank you! As far as we currently know, the following authorities are considering the following options to be correct or not. Authority Reported Answer Hungary Not C Poland B Austro Not D We would say if your country is not Hungary or Poland, go for C. FLUTTER Flutter occurs because a wing (or other aerodynamic surface) is not perfectly stiff, and will bend and twist under high aerodynamic loads. The control surfaces can cause a cyclic movement where the wing moves but the control surface "lags behind", creating an even larger force on the wing. The wing will then do the same thing in the opposite direction, and at certain frequencies can build up to a large, short term oscillation that can cause significant damage ton the aircraft. The risk of experiencing flutter increases with IAS. A control surface oscillation can also be intensified or created by any slack (free play) in the control lines, where the control surface can move freely without pilot input. This means that small disturbances such as turbulence could cause un-commanded control surface movements, which then begin a period of flutter, as eluded to in the question. To go through the options: "This phugoid-type oscillation is likely to increase in magnitude and the aeroplane may enter a stall or encounter an overspeed situation if the oscillation worsens." It is not a phugoid type oscillation being described, as a phugoid has a greater time period than this short interval flutter. "A poorly balanced control surface is creating excessive restoring forces and this short-period motion may cause excessive stress on the airframe." The control surface is not necessarily poorly balanced; the cause of the flutter is the free play in the control lines, so we would say this is not correct. However, the rest of the option is correct, so it's not far off. "The flutter may gradually worsen, and the elevator may vibrate so vigorously that it comes off the hinges and separates from the aeroplane in flight." We believe this is fully correct. The free play in the control lines can cause this kind of response. "Compared to a phugoid, the short period motion leads to a change in pitch and speed, which, if NOT corrected, may lead to a stall or overspeed situation." For a while, the Polish ULC considered this to be correct (we believe), but recent feedback indicates they no longer do. The short period motion doesn't really cause large speed changes (that would be a phugoid) and therefore it is not very likely to cause a stall or overspeed situation.

content.question:
The VA speed of a light aircraft is 133 kt. Determine the aircraft's limit load factor, given the following information from the airspeed indicator.
Green arc: 73 kt - 177 kt
White arc: 53 kt - 104 kt
VNE: 185 kt

options.D: Can't be calculated.

key_points: An aircraft has a limit load factor, that signifies the maximum G-force that the aircraft can handle, before potential damage may occur to the airframe
VA is an aircraft's manoeuvring speed, and exists where the aircraft can handle exactly its limit load factor before stalling
If the aircraft is flying slower than VA, then it will stall before reaching the limit load factor, and if it flying above VA, the limit load factor can be exceeded before stalling
learning.explanation: An aircraft has a limit load factor, that signifies the maximum G-force that the aircraft can handle, before potential damage may occur to the airframe. VA is an aircraft's manoeuvring speed, and exists where the aircraft can handle exactly its limit load factor before stalling. If the aircraft is flying slower than VA, then it will stall before reaching the limit load factor, and if it flying above VA, the limit load factor can be exceeded before stalling. We can therefore use VA in calculations, as it is the stall speed of an aircraft at it's limit load factor. Stall speed calculations are based on the lift force required by the wings, and that varies with weight and load factor (G-force). The higher the weight, or the higher the load factor, the higher airspeed that is required (more airflow makes the wing able to produce greater forces before stalling). For load factor, the formula is: New VS = VS(1G) x sqrt(load factor) Where VS(1G) is the stall speed at 1G (straight level flight) So for the manoeuvring speed VA = VS(1G) x sqrt(limit load factor) We can then re-arrange this to find the limit load factor if we know the VA and the VS(1G) (which we do in this question). The VS(1G) is given in the question as the bottom of the green arc. (VA / VS(1G))2 = limit load factor Limit load factor = (133/73)2 = 3.3 G

content.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the speeds VMO and VC?

options.A: VMO must be equal to VC.
options.B: VMO must be equal to or greater than VC.
options.C: VMO must NOT be greater than VC.
options.D: VMO must NOT be greater than 0.8 x VC.

key_points: Learning Objective 081
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.06.02.01.05: Describe the relationship between VMO or VNE and VC. All aircraft have limitations to their speed and the loads that they can sustain at those speeds. In particular, we have to know about the load/speed diagram for CS-25 (large) aeroplanes. There is a diagram for the maximum load factors (positive and negative) that an aircraft can sustain, whether that limit was to do with a stall limit, or a structural load factor limit. There is also a limiting gust envelope diagram for the maximum gusts an aircraft must be able to handle at various speeds, see annex above. This creates some set design speeds for the aircraft, such as VA, VB, VC and VD. VA - Manoeuvring Speed, the speed where the aircraft will stall at exactly the limiting load factor (2.5 G for CS-25 aircraft). VB - Design Speed for Maximum Gust Intensity, the speed where an aircraft must be able to manage a gust of up to 66 fps. VC - Design Cruise Speed, the maximum speed an aircraft is able to cruise at, giving sufficient safety margin to VD, and means the aircraft will not exceed VD if a particular disturbance occurs when cruising at VC. It is also the point where gusts of up to 50 fps should be managed by the airframe. VC should not be more than 0.8 x VD. VD - Design Dive Speed, the maximum speed that the aircraft can handle in a dive, often limited by vibrations, buffet or flutter. This is the absolute speed limit of the airframe, and the aircraft should be able to manage 25 fps gusts at this speed. To keep the aircraft within safe operation, the VMO (maximum operating speed) must be kept below VC. This is still very fast, and should not be exceeded in normal operations.

content.question: The lift coefficient (CL) of an aeroplane in steady horizontal flight is 0.35. An increase in angle of attack of 1 degree would increase CL by 0.079. If a vertical gust instantly changes the angle of attack by 2 degrees, the load factor will be:

key_points: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical
The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor
The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor
learning.explanation: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical. The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor. The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor. The gust load is the extra load imparted to the airplane by vertical gusts or turbulence. Its magnitude is unaffected by increased altitude but is increased with increased aspect ratio and/or decreased mass. The load factor for any given angle of attack can be derived from the basic load factor for the normal cruise angle of attack because it is increased by the same percentage as the increase of angle of attack. It can be defined by: load factor(n) = (Lift(L))/(Weight(W)) In straight and level flight, Lift = Weight, thus n = 1. In this exercise, the increment in CL from a gust will be of 0.079 for every degree of angle of attack impacted by the gust. We also know that the aircraft encounters a gust which increases its angle of attack by 2°. In straight and level flight n = 1 or: n = 0.35/0.35 A 2° increase in angle of attack, 2*0.079 = 0.158 Will give an increment of 0.45 in the CL: 0.35+0.158 = 0.508 A gust which increases the angle of attack by 2° will increase the load factor to: n = 0.508/0.35 ≈ 1.45 g

content.question:
Which of these statements about the gust load factor on an aeroplane are correct or incorrect?
I. When the mass decreases, the gust load factor increases.
II. When the altitude increases, the gust load factor increases.

options.A: I is correct, II is correct.
options.B: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is correct, II is incorrect.

key_points: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical
The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor
The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor
learning.explanation: A gust is a localized sudden and rapid change to the speed of the air in the atmosphere that can be either horizontal or vertical. The horizontal gust is of little importance because it causes a change to an airplane’s dynamic pressure that results in an insignificant change to the load factor. The vertical gusts are far more important because they change the effective angle of attack, total lift, and the load factor. The gust load is the extra load imparted to the airplane by vertical gusts or turbulence. Its magnitude is unaffected by increased altitude but is increased with increased aspect ratio and/or decreased mass. The load factor for any given angle of attack can be derived from the basic load factor for the normal cruise angle of attack because it is increased by the same percentage as the increase of angle of attack. The load factor deriving from a gust is determined by the magnitude of the vertical velocity of the gust and the forward speed of the airplane. High wing loading reduces the ‘g’ increment in a gust. This is because the lift increment produced is a smaller proportion of the original lift force for the more heavily loaded aircraft. For a given TAS and gust speed, the increase of lift will be proportional to the wing area. Therefore, the increase in load factor is inversely proportional to the wing loading. WingLoading = Weight/(WingArea) Decreasing mass, decreases wing loading which increases load factor. Therefore, statement 1 is correct. With increasing altitude, density decreases and any aerodynamic force resulting from a gust will be smaller. Thus, when comparing two aircraft flying at different altitudes, the one flying in thinner air (higher altitude) will experience a decreased increment in load factor following a gust. Therefore, statement 2 is incorrect.

learning.explanation: At sea level, the TAS is comparitively low and the speed of sound is quite high. At high altitude (for a given CAS), the TAS is much higher, because the air is thin and the local speed of sound (LSS) is less, because it is colder. Because the Mach number is TAS divided by LSS, this means in turn that at altitude, your Mach number is higher for a given CAS, than it is at low level. The result of this is that, as you climb, the maximum speed is controlled at low level by CAS and VMO, and at altitude you reach your limiting Mach number MMO, before you reach VMO and therefore your maximum speed is controlled by MMO. In the descent the reverse is true. Your maximum speed is controlled by MMO first, and then by VMO at lower altitudes. Alternatively, LSS increases during the descent, due to the rising temperature. Therefore, TAS must increase during descent to maintain constant Mach No. IAS is also increasing and will eventually reach its limit. VMO ("max operating") is the term for the maximum certified IAS. NOTE: You can also advice the ECTM lines to show that IAS increases with constant Mach.

learning.explanation: Aircraft can be certified under 2 different certification specifications; CS-23 or CS-25. CS-23 covers "small aircraft". CS-23 also covers commuter category aircraft up to 8618 kg MTOW and a MOPSC of 19 or fewer. This means that there are CS-23 aircraft with an MTOW above 5670 kg. CS-25 covers "large aircraft". There is a difference between the limiting flight airspeeds, VNE and VMO/MMO. Some aircraft (usually smaller, slower aircraft) use VNE - the never exceed speed, and a corresponding VNO, the normal operating speed, which should only be exceeded in smooth air (bottom of the yellow arc). Larger/faster aircraft use VMO/MMO - the maximum operating speed/maximum operating Mach number. This is calculated a little differently to VNE, and is a speed that should not be exceeded during normal operations. An aircraft either has VNE or VMO/MMO, never both. key_points: In the event of an engine failure both the engine and the propeller will slow down
The CSU will attempt to maintain the selected RPM by driving the propeller blades to a fine position that will continue until reaching the fine pitch stop

Despite the engine failing the airplane still has forward speed, for a single-engine airplane due to the glide descent the forward speed causes the propeller to have a negative angle of attack due to the direction of the relative airflow
learning.explanation: In the event of an engine failure both the engine and the propeller will slow down. The CSU will attempt to maintain the selected RPM by driving the propeller blades to a fine position that will continue until reaching the fine pitch stop. Despite the engine failing the airplane still has forward speed, for a single-engine airplane due to the glide descent the forward speed causes the propeller to have a negative angle of attack due to the direction of the relative airflow. This angle of attack generates sufficient torque to rotate the unpowered propeller in the normal direction of rotation. The component of the force at right angles to the plane of rotation now acts rearwards and is no longer thrust but is now drag and presents a flat disc to the direction of travel. Because the propeller is being driven only by the relative airflow it is said to be wind milling. As such, it causes a considerable amount of drag, reduces the IAS, reduces the Lift/Drag ratio and increases the rate of descent.

We have gone with the real life answer initially as this seems most likely, but please let us know if you have any information that does not support this assumption from the real exam, thank you! Fixed pitch propellers are most efficient at a certain TAS value (for a certain RPM - which we are assuming), as this is where the angle of attack of the incoming airflow is the optimum angle of attack (similar to how a wing has an optimum angle of attack), where the lift to drag ratio is highest, to provide the most thrust for the least backwards torque on the engine
learning.explanation: Note: We are not sure how pedantic the examiner wishes to be here. If they are favouring real life, one answer is correct, but if they are being very pedantic about "exact theory" then the answer could be a different one. We have gone with the real life answer initially as this seems most likely, but please let us know if you have any information that does not support this assumption from the real exam, thank you! Fixed pitch propellers are most efficient at a certain TAS value (for a certain RPM - which we are assuming), as this is where the angle of attack of the incoming airflow is the optimum angle of attack (similar to how a wing has an optimum angle of attack), where the lift to drag ratio is highest, to provide the most thrust for the least backwards torque on the engine. This can severely limit the cruise speed of aircraft with fixed pitch props, and therefore, aircraft are equipped with different pitch props based on their expected use-cases. slow training aircraft are equipped with fine pitch "climb" propellers and cruise focussed aircraft are equipped with coarser "cruise" propellers, so they are most capable in their expected speed range. Constant speed (variable pitch) propellers do not have the same disadvantages, as they can change their blade angle to have a much greater band of maximum efficiency. They will therefore be fine for take-off and low speeds, but the constant speed unit will increase the blade angle to keep it more efficient at higher true airspeeds. Therefore, when brakes are released on take-off, the propeller starts getting more efficient as it accelerates, until the propeller angle of attack reaches its optimum, and then after that, the propeller can be made to stay at optimum efficiency after this, in the climb and up to a much higher cruise TAS. The only problem here is that the graph above shows the "optimum" band as being not quite level. This is the case due to a few factors, such as the propeller twist being optimum at a certain speed, etc., but we think that this small effect is not what the examiner is asking about, particularly for the speed range discussed in the question.

key_points: Solidity is the ratio of the propeller blade's frontal area to the propeller disc area
Higher solidity allows for greater power absorption, which can be achieved by increasing the blade chord or adding more blades
Aircraft with more powerful engines often have more blades, but practical limits exist for the number of blades
learning.explanation: Solidity is the ratio of the propeller blade's frontal area to the propeller disc area. Higher solidity allows for greater power absorption, which can be achieved by increasing the blade chord or adding more blades. Aircraft with more powerful engines often have more blades, but practical limits exist for the number of blades. Adding more blades complicates the hub design and increases the centrifugal forces acting on it. Efficiency decreases beyond approximately six blades due to interference between blades. Each blade creates an inflow that reinforces the downwash from the preceding blade, altering the effective relative airflow and necessitating a greater blade angle of attack to maintain the required effective angle of attack. Propeller solidity = Propeller blade frontal area ÷ Propeller disc area

Propellers generate 4 main secondary effects on an aircraft: Torque effect Gyroscopic precession Slipstream Asymmetric blade effect For this question, we can go through each statement and check whether the effect is correct or not for the scenario
learning.explanation: Note: This question was generated based on feedback which was posted on question 813311. Propellers generate 4 main secondary effects on an aircraft: Torque effect Gyroscopic precession Slipstream Asymmetric blade effect For this question, we can go through each statement and check whether the effect is correct or not for the scenario. 1. SLIPSTREAM The spinning of the propeller affects the air that it pushes backwards, and imparts a spiral onto that air, in this case spiralling anti-clockwise around the aircraft, hitting the tail fin on the right hand side, causing a tail-left, nose-right moment. The slipstream increases with an increase in thrust, causing a yaw to the right. Statement 1 is incorrect. 2. TORQUE EFFECT The anti-clockwise rotating propeller gains more anti-clockwise rotational momentum when the pilot adds thrust (higher RPM), so the aircraft experiences the opposite (clockwise) rotation, and is rolled to the right (this can be corrected using left aileron). Statement 1 is correct. 3. GYROSCOPIC PRECESSION The propeller is a mass, spinning at high speed, and therefore acts as a gyroscope. That means that any rotation of the aircraft in pitch or yaw will gain a different force from the propeller due to gyroscopic precession. The force from the propeller will be rotated by 90º in the direction of rotation. In this case, the pitch-up will cause an forward force on the bottom of the propeller disc, which is rotated by precession to a forwards force on the right of the propeller disc. This creates a yaw to the left. Statement 2 is therefore incorrect. 4. ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT The asymmetric blade effect comes from the aircraft being at an angle of attack to the air, so the air does not flow perpendicular to the propeller disc. The down-going propeller blades always produce more thrust than the up-going blades, so the thrust line of this anti-clockwise propeller is to the left of centre. An increase in thrust will therefore cause a larger force through this location (left of centre), which yaws the aircraft to the right. Statement 4 is correct.

learning.explanation: The purpose of a variable-pitch propeller is to either manually or automatically maintain the optimum angle of attack to maximize the lift/drag ratio of the propeller as the airplane speed changes. This characteristic is the most significant advantage of the constant-speed (fixed RPM) propeller over the fixed-pitch propeller because it is able to maintain maximum efficiency over a range of airplane speeds. key_points: This is not too often mentioned in the ATPL exams, and can get quite complicated very quickly if you dig too far, but we will keep it simple

Naturally, there are a few different forces acting on a propeller blade: Torque force - acting against the direction of rotation (against the engine torque) Thrust force - acting in the direction of flight (perpendicular to the plane of rotation)
(this can be a negative force when windmilling or providing reverse thrust)
learning.explanation: This is not too often mentioned in the ATPL exams, and can get quite complicated very quickly if you dig too far, but we will keep it simple. Naturally, there are a few different forces acting on a propeller blade: Torque force - acting against the direction of rotation (against the engine torque) Thrust force - acting in the direction of flight (perpendicular to the plane of rotation). (this can be a negative force when windmilling or providing reverse thrust). There are also a few different moments (bending/twisting forces on the propeller blades) Torque bending force - causing the tips to lag behind the blade hubs due to the torque force. Thrust bending force - bending the edges of the propeller disc in the direction of flight due to the thrust force. Centrifugal twisting moment (CTM) - twisting the propeller to the "fine" direction due to the centrifugal pulling force on the blade (trying to flatten the blade onto the plane of rotation). Aerodynamic twisting moment (ATM) - twisting the propeller to the "coarse" direction (unless windmilling) due to the location of the centre of pressure ahead of the point of rotation. The torque bending moment and thrust bending force are not usually asked in the exams, but the CTM and ATMs are a larger part of the syllabus (though still very rare). Between the CTM and the ATM, they work in opposite directions and CTM is stronger (except when the propeller is windmilling when they work in the same direction (both to "fine")). In this case, the CTM (Centrifugal Twisting Moment) is the correct answer as it tries to decrease the blade pitch angle (make the blade more fine).
