key_points: Asymmetric blade effect (also known as ‘P’ Factor) Propeller blades are not flat, they are in fact shaped as small wings

As a consequence, as the angle of attack of the airplane increases, the air passing by hits the blades differently: The down-going blade (viewed from the cockpit) will have a larger angle of attack compared to the up-going blade, generating more thrust
This then means that the down-swinging (right) blade exerts a greater force than the up-going blade
learning.explanation: Asymmetric blade effect (also known as ‘P’ Factor) Propeller blades are not flat, they are in fact shaped as small wings. As a consequence, as the angle of attack of the airplane increases, the air passing by hits the blades differently: The down-going blade (viewed from the cockpit) will have a larger angle of attack compared to the up-going blade, generating more thrust. This then means that the down-swinging (right) blade exerts a greater force than the up-going blade. For this reason, the thrust line will be displaced to the right of the engine centre line. If both engines rotate clockwise, the right engine will have a longer thrust arm than the left engine. This difference in thrust will give a yawing moment to the left with a clockwise rotating propeller in a nose-up attitude. This effect will be greatest at full power and low airspeed.

key_points: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage

The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT (figure 1) This effect occurs when the axis of rotation of the propeller is inclined to the direction of flight
For example, when the tail wheel on a tail-dragger type aircraft is in contact with the ground, its longitudinal axis inclines above the horizontal
learning.explanation: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage. The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT (figure 1) This effect occurs when the axis of rotation of the propeller is inclined to the direction of flight. For example, when the tail wheel on a tail-dragger type aircraft is in contact with the ground, its longitudinal axis inclines above the horizontal. This causes the down-going blade to have a greater effective angle of attack than the up-going blade, thus developing greater thrust. The thrust asymmetry between the two blades causes the aircraft to yaw to the left. GYROSCOPIC EFFECT (figure 2) A rotating propeller has the properties of a gyroscope - rigidity in space and precession. The characteristic which produces “gyroscopic effect” is precession. Gyroscopic precession is the reaction that occurs when a force is applied to the rim of a rotating disc. When a force is applied to the rim of a propeller, the reaction occurs 90° ahead in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. As the aircraft is pitched up or down or yawed left or right, a force is applied to the rim of the spinning propeller disc. Note: Gyroscopic effect only occurs when the aircraft pitches and/or yaws. For a clockwise rotating propeller: Pitch down - forward force on the top, force emerges 90° clockwise, left yaw. Left yaw - forward force on the right, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch up. Pitch up - forward force on the bottom, force emerges 90° clockwise, right yaw. Right yaw - forward force on the left, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch down.

Which of the following propeller forces and effects contributed to this loss of control?

options.A: Gyroscopic precession
options.B: Spiral slipstream
options.C: Asymmetric blade effect
options.D: Propeller drag

key_points: The high-speed rotation of an aircraft propeller gives a corkscrew or spiraling rotation to the slipstream

At high propeller speeds and low forward speed (as in the take-offs and approaches to power-on stalls), this spiraling rotation is very compact and exerts a strong sideward force on the aircraft’s vertical tail surface
When this spiralling slipstream strikes the vertical fin, it causes a yawing moment about the aircraft’s vertical axis
learning.explanation: The high-speed rotation of an aircraft propeller gives a corkscrew or spiraling rotation to the slipstream. At high propeller speeds and low forward speed (as in the take-offs and approaches to power-on stalls), this spiraling rotation is very compact and exerts a strong sideward force on the aircraft’s vertical tail surface. When this spiralling slipstream strikes the vertical fin, it causes a yawing moment about the aircraft’s vertical axis. The more compact the spiral, the more prominent this force is. On clockwise-rotating propellers, the spiralling slipstream causes a yawing moment to the left. As the forward speed increases, however, the spiral elongates and becomes less effective. The corkscrew flow of the slipstream also causes a rolling moment around the longitudinal axis. Note: Asymmetric blade effect and gyroscopic precession occur during rotation; since this question specifies the period before rotation, these factors are not correct.

content.question: A multi-engined piston aeroplane is in the cruise at FL210 flying over the Alps when one propeller suffers a problem with the anti-icing system and icing starts to build up on one of the propellers. Which of the following is a possible hazard of propeller icing?

options.A: Reduced propeller efficiency means that the aircraft can NOT maintain cruising altitude.
options.B: The propeller mass becomes severely imbalanced and results in damages to the propeller.
options.C: Reduced thrust available means that the aircraft can NOT remain safely airborne.
options.D: Ice breaking off the propeller and damaging the landing gear wheels.

key_points: Ice contamination on the propeller has the same effect as ice on the wings, in that both reduce the efficiency of the aerofoils
Leading edge ice on the propeller reduces the generated thrust in the same way the lift of the wing is reduced
Ice on a propeller blade reduces the efficiency of the propeller and reduces thrust
learning.explanation: Ice contamination on the propeller has the same effect as ice on the wings, in that both reduce the efficiency of the aerofoils. Leading edge ice on the propeller reduces the generated thrust in the same way the lift of the wing is reduced. Ice on a propeller blade reduces the efficiency of the propeller and reduces thrust. In addition, the weight of the ice increases the aircraft weight and therefore the lift required. If ice builds on an unprotected propeller, thrust reduces and you might not be able to climb out of the icing conditions or maintain the altitude. The greatest quantity of ice normally collects on the spinner and inner radius of the propeller. The estimated propeller efficiency loss is on the order of 15%-20%.

content.question: Which type of force tends to decrease the angle of attack on a propeller (fixed or variable pitch)?

options.B: Centrifugal force.

key_points: The centrifugal force to which a rotating propeller is subject creates tensile stress at the blade root and a torque across the chord of the blade, about the pitch-change axis
The centrifugal force (CF) acting along a radial from the propeller hub is divided into components parallel to the pitch-change axis and at right angles to that axis

Because in normal flight the propeller blade has a positive angle of attack the blade leading edge is above the blade trailing edge, which creates a twisting moment about the pitch-change axis (the blade’s longitudinal axis) attempting to bring the blade mass in line with the plane of rotation
learning.explanation: The centrifugal force to which a rotating propeller is subject creates tensile stress at the blade root and a torque across the chord of the blade, about the pitch-change axis. The centrifugal force (CF) acting along a radial from the propeller hub is divided into components parallel to the pitch-change axis and at right angles to that axis. Because in normal flight the propeller blade has a positive angle of attack the blade leading edge is above the blade trailing edge, which creates a twisting moment about the pitch-change axis (the blade’s longitudinal axis) attempting to bring the blade mass in line with the plane of rotation. The Centrifugal Twisting Moment tends to decrease the blade angle of attack, thereby ‘fining’ the pitch. Therefore, the fitted pitch-change mechanism requires little energy to reduce the blade angle but needs a lot more effort to increase the blade angle, i.e. coarsen the propeller pitch.

options.B: Decrease thrust due to increase AoA.
options.C: Increases thrust.

key_points: Ice on an aerofoil changes its properties, reducing lift and increasing drag for a given angle of attack
Ice on a propeller blade reduces the efficiency of the propeller and reduces thrust
As the drag of an ice contaminated airplane increases, the resisting force on the propeller increases for a given RPM and blade angle
learning.explanation: Ice on an aerofoil changes its properties, reducing lift and increasing drag for a given angle of attack. Ice on a propeller blade reduces the efficiency of the propeller and reduces thrust. As the drag of an ice contaminated airplane increases, the resisting force on the propeller increases for a given RPM and blade angle. Since ice on the propeller blades reduces the available thrust, extra power may be required from the engine to overcome the increased drag, decreasing propeller efficiency. Note: Propeller icing can be expected to reduce propeller efficiency by up to 10% normally, but could up to 20% in very severe icing. Propeller icing occurs on the leading edge, but is least at the tip of the blade, where the high rotational speed tends to shed the ice more easily.

key_points: For a multi-engine airplane, the largest asymmetric thrust moment occurs when an outboard engine fails

During a crosswind take-off an airplane tends to weathercock into wind
learning.explanation: For a multi-engine airplane, the largest asymmetric thrust moment occurs when an outboard engine fails. That engine failure which most adversely affects the performance is deemed the critical power unit and is used to determine the limiting control speeds that will ensure adequate directional control in such an event. Because of this the failure of the outboard engine on the windward side of the airplane is the most difficult to counteract and is, therefore, the critical engine for jet-propelled aircraft. For propeller-driven airplanes the direction of propeller rotation determines the critical engine. Viewed from behind, a clockwise rotation dictates that the outboard left engine is critical.

learning.explanation: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage. The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect SLIPSTREAM EFFECT (figure 1) The high-speed rotation of an aircraft propeller gives a corkscrew or spiralling rotation to the slipstream. At high propeller speeds and low forward speed (as in the take-offs and approaches to power-on stalls), this spiralling rotation is very compact and exerts a strong sideward force on the aircraft’s vertical tail surface. When this spiralling slipstream strikes the vertical fin, it causes a yawing moment about the aircraft’s vertical axis. The more compact the spiral, the more prominent this force is. As the forward speed increases, however, the spiral elongates and becomes less effective. The corkscrew flow of the slipstream also causes a rolling moment around the longitudinal axis. GYROSCOPIC EFFECT (figure 2) A rotating propeller has the properties of a gyroscope - rigidity in space and precession. The characteristic which produces “gyroscopic effect” is precession. Gyroscopic precession is the reaction that occurs when a force is applied to the rim of a rotating disc. When a force is applied to the rim of a propeller, the reaction occurs 90° ahead in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. As the aircraft is pitched up or down or yawed left or right, a force is applied to the rim of the spinning propeller disc. Note: Gyroscopic effect only occurs when the aircraft pitches and/or yaws. For a clockwise rotating propeller: Pitch down - forward force on the top, force emerges 90° clockwise, left yaw. Left yaw - forward force on the right, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch up. Pitch up - forward force on the bottom, force emerges 90° clockwise, right yaw. Right yaw - forward force on the left, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch down.

key_points: The propeller shaft inclines upwards due to the angle of attack of the airplane

learning.explanation: The propeller shaft inclines upwards due to the angle of attack of the airplane. Consequently, the down-going propeller blade experiences a greater effective angle of attack compared to the up-going blade, owing to a slight relative forward movement. This results in the down-going (right) blade generating slightly more thrust. As a consequence, the line of thrust shifts right of the propeller cone. Consequently, the left thrust arm is smaller than the right thrust arm. The difference in thrust on both sides of the propeller disc induces a yawing moment to the left when the propeller rotates clockwise in a nose-up attitude. This phenomenon, known as asymmetric blade effect or P-factor, is most pronounced at full power and low airspeed, primarily due to the high angle of attack experienced during takeoff, climb, and go-around maneuvers. Note: The gyroscopic precession of the propeller results in a force applied perpendicular to the plane of rotation appearing to act 90° in the direction of rotation. When the aircraft turns left, a force is applied to the propeller on the right-hand side when viewed from behind. This force, appearing 90° later in this scenario, would be at the bottom of the propeller, causing the aircraft to pitch up.

Adding more blades: A propeller with multiple blades generates an inflow, as each blade enhances the downwash from the previous blade. This inflow modifies the effective relative airflow, necessitating a greater blade angle of attack to achieve the required effective angle of attack. Propeller solidity = Propeller blade frontal area ÷ Propeller disc area

key_points: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage

learning.explanation: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage. The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect Gyroscopic Effect A rotating propeller has the properties of a gyroscope - rigidity in space and precession. The characteristic which produces “gyroscopic effect” is precession. Gyroscopic precession is the reaction that occurs when a force is applied to the rim of a rotating disc. When a force is applied to the rim of a propeller, the reaction occurs 90° ahead in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. As the aircraft is pitched up or down or yawed left or right, a force is applied to the rim of the spinning propeller disc. Note: Gyroscopic effect only occurs when the aircraft pitches and/or yaws. For a clockwise rotating propeller: Pitch up - forward force on the bottom, force emerges 90° clockwise, right yaw. Right yaw - forward force on the left, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch down. Pitch down - forward force on the top, force emerges 90° clockwise, left yaw. Therefore, statement 1 is incorrect. Left yaw - forward force on the right, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch up. Therefore, statement 2 is correct.

content.question: Why is a propeller blade twisted from root to tip?

options.A: To ensure the angle of attack is greatest at the tip.
options.B: To ensure that the tip produces most thrust.
options.C: To ensure that the root produces most thrust.
options.D: To maintain a constant angle of attack along the whole length of the propeller blade.

key_points: As propellers are spinning blades, the tips are travelling much further than the roots during each rotation, but in the same amount of time
The propeller tips are therefore going much faster than the blade root, and this is all lateral speed (i
e
learning.explanation: As propellers are spinning blades, the tips are travelling much further than the roots during each rotation, but in the same amount of time. The propeller tips are therefore going much faster than the blade root, and this is all lateral speed (i.e. not forwards speed). The forwards speed of airflow into the propeller is the same for all sections of the blade, but the lateral speed of the propeller varies massively along the length of the blade. This means the angle of the oncoming airflow is very different for the propeller tip as for the root (near the hub). For this reason, the propeller blade is twisted very significantly between the root and the tip, in order to make sure that the angle of attack remains roughly constant along the length of the blade. The root of the propeller has a very large blade angle and the tip has a much smaller blade angle, but - at the optimum RPM and forwards speed (TAS) - the angle of attack of the whole propeller should be close to the optimum angle of attack. As for the other options, neither the root nor the tip produces most thrust, it is maximum around 75% radius. The root is travelling too slowly to produce much thrust and tip losses means that the thrust drops off in that region also.

Assuming that propeller RPM and blade pitch angle remains constant, at a low speed the angle of attack will be large, giving a lot of thrust
Alpha will reduce with increasing speed and at about 4 degrees the blade will be operating at its best lift/drag ratio, i
learning.explanation: The figure shows the changes that take place as the aircraft speed (TAS) increases. Assuming that propeller RPM and blade pitch angle remains constant, at a low speed the angle of attack will be large, giving a lot of thrust. Alpha will reduce with increasing speed and at about 4 degrees the blade will be operating at its best lift/drag ratio, i.e. the propeller is achieving its highest efficiency. Higher speeds (maybe in a dive) will reduce the blade angle of attack to its zero lift value of about minus 4 degrees. At this point, the propeller will be producing zero thrust. The thrust that is produced by the propeller depends on the angle of attack of the blade. The angle of attack of the blade depends in turn on the airspeed and induced airflow through the propeller. At low airspeeds the angle of attack will be large, near the stall, and thrust will be at its maximum. As forward speed increases, the angle of attack decreases and thrust reduces. That means that the maximum thrust produced by a propeller driven aircraft, also occurs at zero forward airspeed and reduces with forward speed. A fixed propeller can only have one optimum combination of forward airspeed and engine RPM and only one optimum propeller efficiency. At all other combinations it operates less efficiently. This effect can be offset to an extent by using a variable pitch propeller, coarsening the blade angle at higher speeds to maintain the optimum angle of attack.

key_points: To prevent the propeller from ‘windmilling’, the propeller blade of a failed engine is rotated from the fine-pitch stop, through the coarse-pitch stop, to reach the angle of attack to the relative airflow that produces zero lift; this is called ‘feathering’ the propeller
It’s usually approximately 85°/90° because this is the best compromise for the whole blade length when accounting for the blade twist

The purpose of this is to reduce drag from the propeller, as the assumption is that the engine has failed in flight, and therefore maximising thrust and reducing drag is necessary to maintain the best possible climb performance
learning.explanation: To prevent the propeller from ‘windmilling’, the propeller blade of a failed engine is rotated from the fine-pitch stop, through the coarse-pitch stop, to reach the angle of attack to the relative airflow that produces zero lift; this is called ‘feathering’ the propeller. It’s usually approximately 85°/90° because this is the best compromise for the whole blade length when accounting for the blade twist. The purpose of this is to reduce drag from the propeller, as the assumption is that the engine has failed in flight, and therefore maximising thrust and reducing drag is necessary to maintain the best possible climb performance. By turning the propeller to the feathered position, there is the minimum frontal area to produce drag, and the propeller is not inclined to rotate, which is the "windmilling" tendency that propellers have: Not only is this bad for drag, it is also bad for continuing to turn the engine and potentially causing further damage or spreading a possible fire, etc. For a single-engine airplane, feathering the propeller blades improves the glide performance due to lower drag, however, having the blade at a fine pitch setting would be better if a restart is to be attempted. As such, feathering the propeller may be used to increase the gliding range/endurance, if it is available. For a multi-engine airplane, the decreased drag improves climb performance, but is also good for reducing the amount of yaw. As the drag of the failed engine propeller acts in the same direction as the thrust asymmetry, getting rid of this extra drag by feathering the propeller makes the thrust asymmetry a little easier to counteract, and this is quite noticeable when doing engine failure training on a twin propeller aircraft. Therefore, the answer is that the left yaw is reduced (not removed completely, of course).

content.question: What causes a powerful old wartime piston single-engine aircraft with a anticlockwise rotating propeller to veer to the right when the throttle is increased to maximum power during take-off?

options.A: Torque effect.
options.B: Gyro effect.
options.C: Asymmetric effect.
options.D: Slipstream effect.

key_points: Propellers generate 4 main secondary effects on an aircraft: Torque effect Gyroscopic precession Slipstream Asymmetric blade effect For this question, we can go through each statement and check whether the effect is correct or not for the scenario

TORQUE EFFECT The anti-clockwise rotating propeller gains more anti-clockwise rotational momentum when the pilot adds thrust (higher RPM), so the aircraft experiences the opposite (clockwise) rotation, and is rolled to the right (this can be corrected using left aileron)
GYROSCOPIC PRECESSION The propeller is a mass, spinning at high speed, and therefore acts as a gyroscope
learning.explanation: Propellers generate 4 main secondary effects on an aircraft: Torque effect Gyroscopic precession Slipstream Asymmetric blade effect For this question, we can go through each statement and check whether the effect is correct or not for the scenario. TORQUE EFFECT The anti-clockwise rotating propeller gains more anti-clockwise rotational momentum when the pilot adds thrust (higher RPM), so the aircraft experiences the opposite (clockwise) rotation, and is rolled to the right (this can be corrected using left aileron). GYROSCOPIC PRECESSION The propeller is a mass, spinning at high speed, and therefore acts as a gyroscope. That means that any rotation of the aircraft in pitch or yaw will gain a different force from the propeller due to gyroscopic precession. The force from the propeller will be rotated by 90º in the direction of rotation. In this case, the pitch-up will cause an forward force on the bottom of the propeller disc, which is rotated by precession to a forwards force on the right of the propeller disc. This creates a yaw to the left. SLIPSTREAM EFFECT The spinning of the propeller affects the air that it pushes backwards, and imparts a spiral onto that air, in this case spiralling anti-clockwise around the aircraft, hitting the tail fin on the right hand side, causing a tail-left, nose-right moment. The slipstream increases with an increase in thrust, causing a yaw to the right. ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT The asymmetric blade effect comes from the aircraft being at an angle of attack to the air, so the air does not flow perpendicular to the propeller disc. The down-going propeller blades always produce more thrust than the up-going blades, so the thrust line of this anti-clockwise propeller is to the left of centre. An increase in thrust will therefore cause a larger force through this location (left of centre), which yaws the aircraft to the right. Note: Asymmetric blade effect and gyroscopic precession come into play at rotation. One could argue that slipstream effect could also be an option. However, according to feedback, “torque effect” was the correct answer.

content.question: You are flying a twin engine aircraft with clockwise rotating propellers, if you get an engine failure what should you do?

options.A: Yaw and roll towards the live engine.
options.B: Roll and yaw to the dead.
options.C: Yaw to the dead, roll live.
options.D: Yaw to the live, roll to the dead.

key_points: Rudder to Stop Yaw - Bank Towards Live Engine This method produces minimum drag and gives the best ability to climb and is the preferred method of putting the aircraft in equilibrium following engine failure

In the event of an engine failure in a non-centerline thrust twin or multi engine aircraft, the operative engine is going to create a strong yawing moment about the vertical axis of the aircraft in the direction of the dead engine

Uncorrected, this results in a forward slip toward the side of the good engine and, when combined with the fuselage blanking airflow over the wing on the dead engine side, a rolling moment also develops about the longitudinal axis in the direction of the dead engine
learning.explanation: Rudder to Stop Yaw - Bank Towards Live Engine This method produces minimum drag and gives the best ability to climb and is the preferred method of putting the aircraft in equilibrium following engine failure. In the event of an engine failure in a non-centerline thrust twin or multi engine aircraft, the operative engine is going to create a strong yawing moment about the vertical axis of the aircraft in the direction of the dead engine. Uncorrected, this results in a forward slip toward the side of the good engine and, when combined with the fuselage blanking airflow over the wing on the dead engine side, a rolling moment also develops about the longitudinal axis in the direction of the dead engine. The typical action is to apply rudder in the direction of the live engine to counteract this forward slip. However, while the nose will be aligned with the desired flight path doing this, the actual flight path is a side slip towards the dead engine side, which creates excess drag. The only available counter to this is to bank the airplane into the direction of the live engine to counteract the rudder force using the horizontal component of lift. The angle of bank must not exceed 5°, to prevent excessive loss of vertical lift component.

learning.explanation: If a multi-engine aircraft suffers an engine failure when airborne, there are two immediate aerodynamic effects: The initial effect is the yawing that occurs due to the asymmetry of the thrust line. The second effect is roll. This occurs when the aircraft continues to yaw towards the failed engine resulting in a decrease in lift from the retreating wing and a yaw-induced roll towards the failed engine. In this case, when experiencing a right engine failure, the aircraft will bank towards the right. This roll will be more marked if the flaps are extended, the left wing will create significantly greater lift.

key_points: In the event of an engine failure of a multi-engine airplane the strength of the asymmetric yawing moment caused by its failure is dependent on the distance of the failed engine from the CG, measured at right angles to the longitudinal axis
The further outboard the failed engine is located the greater is the induced yawing moment

Because the engines of a propeller-driven airplane have to be mounted on the wing sufficiently far from the fuselage to account the necessary propeller clearance then these airplanes always experience a large yawing moment when an engine fails that may be difficult to control
learning.explanation: In the event of an engine failure of a multi-engine airplane the strength of the asymmetric yawing moment caused by its failure is dependent on the distance of the failed engine from the CG, measured at right angles to the longitudinal axis. The further outboard the failed engine is located the greater is the induced yawing moment. Because the engines of a propeller-driven airplane have to be mounted on the wing sufficiently far from the fuselage to account the necessary propeller clearance then these airplanes always experience a large yawing moment when an engine fails that may be difficult to control. This is not so with a jet airplane because the wing-mounted engines on these airplanes can be mounted relatively close to the fuselage thus creating a relatively short moment arm, which produces a small yawing moment that is easier to control. In such a situation the propeller-driven airplane also has a greater tendency to roll than the jet-propelled airplane. On suffering an engine failure, the unbalanced thrust and drag produces a yawing moment that must be counteracted by the deflection of the rudder. The side force generated by the rudder deflection when multiplied by the moment arm (the distance that the center of pressure of the rudder is from the CG) has to produce a counteracting moment equal to and opposite to the yawing moment.

This seems like the worst in our opinion, but at least all the other options are significantly incorrect, so it makes it easy enough to answer, even if not truly correct. This could show up differently in the exam anyway, so as long as you know the simple theory behind it, you should have no problem. The efficiency of any system is determined by the ratio of the output power to the input power. The force developed by the engine and delivered to the propeller via the shaft is the rotational force of the propeller, the propeller torque. The power delivered from the shaft to the propeller (input power) is the product of the torque and the angular velocity of the propeller shaft (Torque × RPM). The thrust developed by the propeller is the product of the mass of air moved and the acceleration given to it by the propeller. The power developed by the propeller is the product of the thrust and the TAS (Thrust × Axial Speed). Propeller efficiency is the ratio of the propeller output power developed to the engine power delivered (input power). A well-designed propeller is typically 80% efficient when operating at its optimum blade angle of attack. Of course, this question doesn't have that as an option, so the closest option is "Thrust produced to power input". The ratio is therefore not correct, as thrust is not power output, they different by a factor of the true airspeed, but it's the closest they have given us. Why they keep using thrust to describe the output of a propeller, we have no idea, as a whole branch of PoF is to do with the fact we only measure propeller power, not thrust. As for the other options: "power input to fuel consumption" is a measure of the engine efficiency. "airspeed to thrust produced" is not really a useful measure of anything. "torque to rotational speed" is not a useful measure either. When these two are multiplied together, they get the input power, but as a ratio, they are useless to us.

key_points: To prevent the propeller from ‘wind milling’ the propeller blade is rotated from the fine-pitch stop through the coarse-pitch stop to reach the angle of attack to the relative airflow that produces zero lift; and referred to as ‘feathering’ the propeller

learning.explanation: To prevent the propeller from ‘wind milling’ the propeller blade is rotated from the fine-pitch stop through the coarse-pitch stop to reach the angle of attack to the relative airflow that produces zero lift; and referred to as ‘feathering’ the propeller. It is usually approximately 85◦ because it is the best compromise for the whole blade length and accounts for the blade twist. This blade position stops the propeller from rotating because there is no lift force to produce a torque reaction; it reduces the drag to a minimum level and prevents damage being caused to the engine. For a single-engine airplane feathering the propeller blades improves the glide performance because it does not require such a steep glide angle to maintain the required airspeed. As such, feathering the propeller increases the gliding range and endurance. For a multi-engine airplane, the decreased drag reduces the amount of thrust required to counteract the asymmetric force of the propeller of the failed engine and there is sufficient rudder authority remaining to enable the pilot to safely control the airplane.

learning.explanation: Ice on an aerofoil changes its properties, reducing lift and increasing drag for a given angle of attack. Ice on a propeller blade reduces the efficiency of the propeller and reduces thrust. In the same way, as the drag of an ice contaminated airplane increases, the resisting force on the propeller increases for a given rpm and blade angle. Ice separating from the propeller blades, as well as vibration due to propeller imbalance, may cause damage to the airplane structure. Since ice on the propeller blades reduces the available thrust, extra power may be required from the engine to overcome the increased drag, decreasing propeller efficiency. Note: Propeller icing can be expected to reduce propeller efficiency by up to 10% normally, but could up to 20% in very severe icing. Propeller icing occurs on the leading edge, but is least at the tip of the blade, where the high rotational speed tends to shed the ice more easily. For that reason, icing will be reduced by INCREASING propeller rpm, not reducing it. The loss of aircraft performance in icing conditions is mainly due to ice formation on the rest of the wings and airframe, with a smaller contribution coming from the propeller icing.

key_points: Note: The propeller governor varies the propeller pitch angle as required to maintain the selected RPM
A propeller is a fan, fitted with between two and six aerodynamic blades that is used to convert rotational motion into forward thrust for the propulsion of an aeroplane through the air
The blades of the propeller are small aerodynamic aerofoils mounted vertically on a horizontal shaft that is rotated by either a piston engine or a turbine-driven engine
learning.explanation: Note: The propeller governor varies the propeller pitch angle as required to maintain the selected RPM. A propeller is a fan, fitted with between two and six aerodynamic blades that is used to convert rotational motion into forward thrust for the propulsion of an aeroplane through the air. The blades of the propeller are small aerodynamic aerofoils mounted vertically on a horizontal shaft that is rotated by either a piston engine or a turbine-driven engine. BLADE ANGLE (PITCH) The angle between the blade chord and the plane of rotation. ANGLE OF ATTACK The path of the propeller through the air determines the direction of the relative airflow. The angle between the blade chord and the relative airflow is the angle of attack (α). The angle of attack (α) is the result of propeller rotational velocity (RPM) and aircraft forward velocity (TAS). Because the rotational velocity of the blade increases with distance from the propeller shaft and the fact that the aeroplane is moving forward, then the angle of attack of the blade varies at different distances from the shaft. CONSTANT SPEED PROPELLER The purpose of a variable-pitch propeller is to either manually or automatically maintain the optimum angle of attack to maximize the lift/drag ratio of the propeller as the aeroplane speed changes. Constant-speed propellers enable the pilot to select the RPM for maximum power or maximum efficiency and a propeller governor varies the propeller pitch angle as required to maintain the selected RPM. FIGURE 1 The diagram shows the conditions during the early stages of the take-off roll. The RPM is set to maximum and the TAS is low. The angle of attack is optimum and maximum available efficiency is obtained. As the aircraft continues to accelerate, the TAS will increase, which decreases the angle of attack of the blades. Less thrust will be generated and less propeller torque. This gives less resistance for the engine to overcome and RPM would tend to increase. The propeller governor senses the RPM increase and increases pitch to maintain the blade angle of attack constant. FIGURE 2 The diagram shows conditions when the engine and propeller have been set for cruise conditions. Optimum throttle and RPM settings are listed in the aircraft Flight Manual. Whatever configuration into which the aircraft is placed, climb, descent or bank, the CSU will adjust the blade angle (propeller pitch) to maintain the RPM which has been set. At least it will try to maintain constant RPM.

content.question: While performing a go-around, an aircraft with a right-hand propeller will initially tend to…

options.A: yaw to the right and roll to the left.
options.B: yaw to the right and roll to the right.
options.C: yaw to the left and roll to the right.
options.D: yaw to the left and roll to the left.

key_points: Note: This is similar to question 814917 but without the story in the question Let's start by considering the roll of the aircraft, it is mainly just affected by the torque effect
TORQUE EFFECT This occurs primarily because the air resists the motion of the propeller
In so doing, it tends to twist the engine and airframe in the opposite direction to the propeller (i
learning.explanation: Note: This is similar to question 814917 but without the story in the question Let's start by considering the roll of the aircraft, it is mainly just affected by the torque effect. TORQUE EFFECT This occurs primarily because the air resists the motion of the propeller. In so doing, it tends to twist the engine and airframe in the opposite direction to the propeller (i.e. anti-clockwise). This causes the aircraft to roll to the left and is particularly noticeable in a go-around scenario, where the airspeed over the ailerons is low, and maximum power is applied, not only causing a large increase in torque effect but also the rotational acceleration of the propeller provides a further effect. So that's why the aircraft will roll to the left in this scenario. But the yaw is, unfortunately, a little more complicated as there are a few extra factors at play, in fact almost all the secondary effects are here. The asymmetric blade effect (P-factor) will cause a yaw to the left; The gyroscopic precession causes a smaller, temporary yaw to the right whilst pitching up; The slipstream effect causes an increased yaw to the left; and Therefore, overall the aircraft yaws to the left, hence the need for more right rudder than you expect if you've trained in an aircraft with a clockwise rotating propeller, which is highly likely. SLIPSTREAM The spinning of the propeller affects the air that it pushes backwards, and imparts a spiral onto that air, in this case spiralling clockwise around the aircraft, hitting the tail fin on the left hand side, causing a tail-right, nose-left moment. The slipstream increases with an increase in thrust, causing a yaw to the left. GYROSCOPIC PRECESSION The propeller is a mass, spinning at high speed, and therefore acts as a gyroscope. That means that any rotation of the aircraft in pitch or yaw will gain a different force from the propeller due to gyroscopic precession. The force from the propeller will be rotated by 90º in the direction of rotation. In this case, the pitch-up will cause a forward force on the bottom of the propeller disc, which is rotated by precession to a forwards force on the left of the propeller disc, which is a transient yaw to the right. ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT The asymmetric blade effect comes from the aircraft being at an angle of attack to the air, so the air does not flow perpendicular to the propeller disc. The down-going propeller blades always produce more thrust than the up-going blades, due to a higher angle of attack, so the thrust line of this clockwise propeller is to the right of centre. An increase in thrust will therefore cause a larger force through this location (right of centre), which yaws the aircraft to the left.

key_points: SECONDARY EFFECTS OF THE PROPELLER Due to its rotation a propeller generates yawing, rolling and pitching moments

learning.explanation: SECONDARY EFFECTS OF THE PROPELLER Due to its rotation a propeller generates yawing, rolling and pitching moments. These are due to several different causes: Torque reaction, Gyroscopic precession, Spiral (asymmetric) slipstream effect and Asymmetric blade effect. Torque reaction. A counter-clockwise rotating propeller produces a clockwise moment that must be counteracted by ailerons. During take-off this will apply a greater down load to the left wheel, causing more rolling resistance on the left wheel making the aircraft want to yaw to the left. Gyroscopic precession. Propeller can also be considered a gyroscope as it is a certain mass, which is rotating. Gyroscopes want to maintain their plane of rotation. When a force is applied to the rim of a propeller, the reaction occurs 90° ahead in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. if an aircraft with a clockwise rotating propeller is pitched nose-up, imagine that a forward force has been applied to the bottom of the propeller disc. The force will “emerge” at 90° in the direction of rotation, i.e. a right yawing moment. Spiral Slipstream. As the propeller rotates it produces a backward flow of air, or slipstream, which rotates around the aircraft. This spiral slipstream causes a change in airflow around the fin (vertical stabilizer). Due to the direction of propeller rotation (clockwise) the spiral slipstream meets the fin at an angle from the left, producing a sideways force on the fin to the right.

learning.explanation: The blade angle of a fixed-pitch propeller is constant, but the helix angle and the angle of attack will vary according to its forward speed. To ensure its efficient operation the blade angle of attack of a fixed-pitch propeller must be close to the optimum and is that which produces the greatest excess of horizontal lift (thrust) over drag. learning.explanation: To prevent the propeller from ‘wind milling’ the propeller blade is rotated from the fine-pitch stop through the coarse-pitch stop to reach the angle of attack to the relative airflow that produces zero lift; and referred to as ‘feathering’ the propeller. It’s usually approximately 85°/90° because it is the best compromise for the whole blade length and accounts for the blade twist. The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect Gyroscopic Effect A rotating propeller has the properties of a gyroscope - rigidity in space and precession. The characteristic which produces “gyroscopic effect” is precession. Gyroscopic precession is the reaction that occurs when a force is applied to the rim of a rotating disc. When a force is applied to the rim of a propeller, the reaction occurs 90° ahead in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. Pitch up - forward force on the bottom, force emerges 90° clockwise, right yaw. Therefore, statement 1 is correct. Right yaw - forward force on the left, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch down. learning.explanation: A propeller is a fan, fitted with between two and six aerodynamic blades that is used to convert rotational motion into forward thrust for the propulsion of an aeroplane through the air. The blades of the propeller are small aerodynamic aerofoils mounted vertically on a horizontal shaft that is rotated by either a piston engine or a turbine-driven engine. BLADE ANGLE (PITCH) The angle between the blade chord and the plane of rotation. ANGLE OF ATTACK The path of the propeller through the air determines the direction of the relative airflow. The angle between the blade chord and the relative airflow is the angle of attack (α). The angle of attack (α) is the result of propeller rotational velocity (RPM) and aircraft forward velocity (TAS). Because the rotational velocity of the blade increases with distance from the propeller shaft and the fact that the aeroplane is moving forward, then the angle of attack of the blade varies at different distances from the shaft. CONSTANT SPEED PROPELLER The purpose of a variable-pitch propeller is to either manually or automatically maintain the optimum angle of attack to maximize the lift/drag ratio of the propeller as the aeroplane speed changes. Constant-speed propellers enable the pilot to select the RPM for maximum power or maximum efficiency and a propeller governor varies the propeller pitch angle as required to maintain the selected RPM. Figure shows the conditions during the early stages of the take-off roll. The RPM is set to maximum and the TAS is low. The angle of attack is optimum and maximum available efficiency is obtained. As the aircraft continues to accelerate, the TAS will increase, which decreases the angle of attack of the blades. Less thrust will be generated and less propeller torque. This gives less resistance for the engine to overcome and RPM would tend to increase. The propeller governor senses the RPM increase and increases pitch to maintain the blade angle of attack constant.

content.question: Which of the following situations decribes the most favourable situation in case of an engine failure on a twin engine aeroplane?

options.A: Failure of the right engine if both engines are counter rotating outwards.
options.B: Failure of the left engine if both engines are rotating in the same direction.
options.C: Failure of the right engine if both engines are counter rotating inwards.
options.D: Failure of the left engine if both engines are counter rotating outwards.

key_points: Asymmetric blade effect (also known as ‘P’ Factor) Propeller blades are not flat, they are in fact shaped the same as wings

As a consequence, as the angle of attack of the airplane increases, the air passing by hits the blades differently: An aircraft rarely flies at 0º Angle of Attack, and is always pitched slightly up from this
This means that the down-going blade will have a larger angle of attack compared to the up-going blade, generating more thrust
learning.explanation: Asymmetric blade effect (also known as ‘P’ Factor) Propeller blades are not flat, they are in fact shaped the same as wings. As a consequence, as the angle of attack of the airplane increases, the air passing by hits the blades differently: An aircraft rarely flies at 0º Angle of Attack, and is always pitched slightly up from this. This means that the down-going blade will have a larger angle of attack compared to the up-going blade, generating more thrust. This then means that the down-going blade exerts a greater force than the up-going blade. For this reason, the thrust line will be displaced to one side of the propeller disc (the down-going section). Propellers both rotating clockwise (same direction): if both engines rotate clockwise, the right engine will have a thrust arm further from the centre of the aircraft. The failure of the left-hand engine will therefore result in a larger yaw effect (as the right hand engine produces power further away from the longitudinal axis). The left engine is therefore the critical engine, as its failure causes a worse power asymmetry. Counter-rotating propellers: Some aircraft are made so the engines rotate the opposite of each other - called counter-rotating. The most effective method is have them both rotate inwards (right engine anticlockwise, left engine clockwise), as the down-going blades are close to the centre of the aircraft, and there is less asymmetry after any engine failure. The question also mentions outwards rotating propellers. These would serve no added purpose, as the asymmetry would be high after either engine failure. Counter rotating propellers have no critical engine, as both failure scenarios produce equal asymmetry. Therefore, the correct option is: Failure of the right engine if both engines are counter rotating inwards, as this guarantees that the thrust vector will be as close to the centre of the aircraft as possible. Note: "The failure of the left engine if both engines are rotating in the same direction" is unknown, because it is correct if the engines are rotating anti-clockwise, but not when the engines are rotating clockwise. As we don't have that information, we can not say it is correct (and also, clockwise rotation is generally more common).

learning.explanation: The purpose of the propeller is to convert the power output from the engine into thrust. The power developed is transmitted to the propeller shaft as engine torque and rotates the propeller. The rotation of a propeller creates a total reactive force at right angles to the chordline of the propeller blade. This can be divided into two components, that which is perpendicular to the relative airflow, the lift, and that which is parallel to the relative airflow, the drag. Thrust acts parallel to the direction of flight, whilst propeller torque (the resistance to the motion in the plane of rotation) acts perpendicular to the direction of flight. The propeller torque must thus be overcome or balanced by engine torque for a propeller section to provide thrust.

content.question: The twist of a propeller blade from hub to tip is to...

options.A: maintain constant thrust along the blade.
options.B: maintain a constant blade angle.
options.C: maintain a constant angle of attack along the blade.
options.D: maintain constant speed.

key_points: Learning Objective 081
learning.explanation: Learning Objective 081.07.01.03.02: Explain why blade twist is necessary. As propellers are spinning blades, the tips are travelling much further than the roots during each rotation, but in the same amount of time. The propeller tips are therefore going much faster than the blade root, and this is all lateral speed (i.e. not forwards speed). The forwards speed of airflow into the propeller is the same for all sections of the blade, but the lateral speed of the propeller varies massively along the length of the blade. This means the angle of the oncoming airflow is very different for the propeller tip as for the root (near the hub). For this reason, the propeller blade is twisted very significantly between the root and the tip, in order to make sure that the angle of attack remains roughly constant along the length of the blade. The root of the propeller has a very large blade angle and the tip has a much smaller blade angle, but - at the optimum RPM and forwards speed (TAS) - the angle of attack of the whole propeller should be close to the optimum angle of attack. As for the other options: The thrust is not meant to be constant at all locations on the propeller, as there is no way to make the slow moving root produce the same amount of thrust as the fast moving tip, and also you don't want the tip to produce too much thrust as it could warp the blade. This one is a common misconception so be sure not to get it wrong. The blade angle is changed by twisting the blade, an un-twisted propeller would have constant blade angle (and very poor performance/efficiency). All sections of the propeller cannot all go at the same speed as this is physically impossible.

learning.explanation: The high-speed rotation of an aircraft propeller gives a corkscrew or spiraling rotation to the slipstream. At high propeller speeds and low forward speed (as in the take-offs and approaches to power-on stalls), this spiraling rotation is very compact and exerts a strong sideward force on the aircraft’s vertical tail surface. When this spiraling slipstream strikes the vertical fin, it causes a yawing moment about the aircraft’s vertical axis. The more compact the spiral, the more prominent this force is. As the forward speed increases, however, the spiral elongates and becomes less effective. The corkscrew flow of the slipstream also causes a rolling moment around the longitudinal axis.

learning.explanation: The high-speed rotation of an aircraft propeller gives a corkscrew or spiraling rotation to the slipstream. At high propeller speeds and low forward speed (as in the take-offs and approaches to power-on stalls), this spiraling rotation is very compact and exerts a strong sideward force on the aircraft’s vertical tail surface. When this spiralling slipstream strikes the vertical fin, it causes a yawing moment about the aircraft’s vertical axis. The more compact the spiral, the more prominent this force is. On clockwise-rotating propellers, the spiralling slipstream causes a yawing moment to the left. As the forward speed increases, however, the spiral elongates and becomes less effective. The corkscrew flow of the slipstream also causes a rolling moment around the longitudinal axis.

learning.explanation: Blade pitch refers to the process of turning the propeller blades’ angle of attack into or out of the wind, depending on the best performance at that point. Propeller pitch is often referred to as ‘coarse’ for a greater horizontal blade angle and ‘fine’ for a more vertical angle. The thrust from a propeller depends on its speed and angle of attack. As the tip of the propeller has a higher speed than the hub, propellers ate often twisted along the blade to remain uniform thrust along the blade. key_points: A propeller blade is just a wing
Anything that happens to a propeller blade can be translated into our knowledge of how a wing behaves

learning.explanation: A propeller blade is just a wing. Anything that happens to a propeller blade can be translated into our knowledge of how a wing behaves. The main difference is that the air interacting with a propeller blade is partially from ahead of the aircraft, brought in by the TAS (True Airspeed) of the aircraft, and the other component of the incoming air is from the rotational speed of the propeller. This means that the angle of relative airflow will change, depending on the RPM and TAS, and their relationship. In the case of this diagram, we have one force being created by the propeller blade, split into two components. Number 1 component is opposing the rotation of the propeller, where number 2 component is in the direction of flight. This makes number 2 quite simple, it is the thrust produced. It is quite a similar force vector to the lift created by a fixed wing. Number 1 is the opposing force of the propeller rotation, and therefore the opposing force to the engine. This means that it is the opposing torque, known sometimes just as "torque" or "torque drag". Torque is the measure of how much force an engine can apply in one rotation, and for an engine at constant RPM, the torque from the engine will match the "torque drag" of the propeller. Notice how, for a wing, number 1 would be closely related to the drag of the wing, hence even easier to remember "torque drag"

key_points: The purpose of a variable-pitch propeller is to either manually or automatically maintain the optimum angle of attack to maximize the lift/drag ratio of the propeller as the airplane speed changes

This characteristic is the most significant advantage of the constant-speed (fixed RPM) propeller over the fixed-pitch propeller because it is able to maintain maximum efficiency over a range of airplane speeds
Originally there were only two pitch settings, fine for take-off and climb and coarse for cruise and high-speed flight
learning.explanation: The purpose of a variable-pitch propeller is to either manually or automatically maintain the optimum angle of attack to maximize the lift/drag ratio of the propeller as the airplane speed changes. This characteristic is the most significant advantage of the constant-speed (fixed RPM) propeller over the fixed-pitch propeller because it is able to maintain maximum efficiency over a range of airplane speeds. Originally there were only two pitch settings, fine for take-off and climb and coarse for cruise and high-speed flight. Subsequently, the fully variable pitch constant-speed propeller was introduced so that the optimum blade angle of attack could be maintained over the whole range of operating speeds for that airplane. This facility not only improves the propeller efficiency but also decreases the fuel consumption. The pitch angle or blade angle of a constant-speed propeller (fixe RPM) increases (or coarsens) with increasing TAS. Constant-speed propellers enable the pilot to select the RPM for maximum power or maximum efficiency and a propeller governor varies the propeller pitch angle as required to maintain the selected RPM. Propeller efficiency improves with increased TAS; however, it is limited to that blade angle beyond which the propeller will no longer produce any thrust.

The geometric pitch is the distance the propeller would travel forward in one complete revolution if it were moving through the air at the blade angle. Despite the engine failing the airplane still has forward speed, for a single-engine airplane due to the glide descent the forward speed causes the propeller to have a negative angle of attack due to the direction of the relative airflow
learning.explanation: In the event of an engine failure both the engine and the propeller will slow down. The CSU will attempt to maintain the selected RPM by driving the propeller blades to a fine position that will continue until reaching the fine pitch stop. Despite the engine failing the airplane still has forward speed, for a single-engine airplane due to the glide descent the forward speed causes the propeller to have a negative angle of attack due to the direction of the relative airflow. This angle of attack generates sufficient torque to rotate the unpowered propeller in the normal direction of rotation. The component of the force at right angles to the plane of rotation now acts rearwards and is no longer thrust but is now drag and presents a flat disc to the direction of travel. Because the propeller is being driven only by the relative airflow it is said to be wind milling. As such, it causes a considerable amount of drag, reduces the IAS, reduces the Lift/Drag ratio and increases the rate of descent.

options.A: lower than
options.B: the same as

key_points: The purpose of the propeller is to convert the power output from the engine into thrust
The power developed is transmitted to the propeller shaft as engine torque and rotates the propeller
The rotation of a propeller creates a total reactive force at right angles to the chordline of the propeller blade
learning.explanation: The purpose of the propeller is to convert the power output from the engine into thrust. The power developed is transmitted to the propeller shaft as engine torque and rotates the propeller. The rotation of a propeller creates a total reactive force at right angles to the chordline of the propeller blade. This can be divided into two components, that which is perpendicular to the relative airflow, the lift, and that which is parallel to the relative airflow, the drag. Thrust acts parallel to the direction of flight, whilst propeller torque (the resistance to the motion in the plane of rotation) acts perpendicular to the direction of flight. The propeller torque must thus be overcome or balanced by engine torque for a propeller section to provide thrust. Engine torque will rotate the propeller and the propeller, while creating thrust (propeller lift) will resist the engine torque with propeller torque (propeller drag). If the engine and propeller torque are in balance, the engine RPM is constant (Newton’s first law of motion)

key_points: At high propeller speeds and low forward speed (as in the take-offs, approaches to power-on stalls or go-around), the aircraft will have the tendecy to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage
The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect TORQUE REACTION This occurs because the air resists the motion of the propeller
In so doing, it tends to twist the engine and airframe in the opposite direction to the propeller (i
learning.explanation: At high propeller speeds and low forward speed (as in the take-offs, approaches to power-on stalls or go-around), the aircraft will have the tendecy to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage. The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect TORQUE REACTION This occurs because the air resists the motion of the propeller. In so doing, it tends to twist the engine and airframe in the opposite direction to the propeller (i.e. counter- clockwise). This causes the aircraft to roll to the left and, whilst on the ground, places more weight on the left wheel than the right wheel. This effectively increases the rolling resistance (i.e. drag) of the left wheel, thus slowing the aircraft down and causing it to yaw to the left. GYROSCOPIC EFFECT Gyroscopic precession is the reaction that occurs when a force is applied to the rim of a rotating disc. When a force is applied to the rim of a propeller, the reaction occurs 90° ahead in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. As the aircraft is pitched up or down or yawed left or right, a force is applied to the rim of the spinning propeller disc.

If unaddressed, the blade root, with its low rotational speed, would experience a very low angle of attack, while the blade tip, with its high rotational speed, would have a very high angle of attack
learning.explanation: For a given RPM, the rotational velocity is much higher at the tip of the blade than at the root. This results in the relative airflow approaching the blade at significantly different angles along its length. If unaddressed, the blade root, with its low rotational speed, would experience a very low angle of attack, while the blade tip, with its high rotational speed, would have a very high angle of attack. To solve this problem and distribute thrust evenly across the propeller, a substantial amount of twist is applied to the blade (much more than the washout twist given to a wing). This blade twist reduces the blade angle from the hub to the tip, maintaining a constant angle of attack. This twist is applied to all blades, whether they have fixed or variable pitch.

key_points: When the propeller is rotating, aerodynamic losses occur near the hub and at the blade tips
Near the hub, the airflow is disrupted where the propeller blade sections are thicker and near the engine
Vortices form at the propeller blade tips in a similar manner as at the wing tips
learning.explanation: When the propeller is rotating, aerodynamic losses occur near the hub and at the blade tips. Near the hub, the airflow is disrupted where the propeller blade sections are thicker and near the engine. Vortices form at the propeller blade tips in a similar manner as at the wing tips. This results in induced drag and a reduction in the actual amount of thrust developed in this region. In practice, only a small part of the propeller blade is effective in producing thrust at normal operating angles of attack. This is generally between 60% and 90% of the distance from the blade hub to the tip. At positive angles of attack, the greatest useful thrust is produced at 75% of the tip radius. Propellers generate 4 main secondary effects on an aircraft: Torque effect Gyroscopic precession Slipstream Asymmetric blade effect For this question, we can go through each statement and check whether the effect is correct or not for the scenario. 1. TORQUE EFFECT The anti-clockwise rotating propeller gains more anti-clockwise rotational momentum when the pilot adds thrust (higher RPM), so the aircraft experiences the opposite (clockwise) rotation, and is rolled to the right (this can be corrected using left aileron). Statement 1 is correct. 2. GYROSCOPIC PRECESSION The propeller is a mass, spinning at high speed, and therefore acts as a gyroscope. That means that any rotation of the aircraft in pitch or yaw will gain a different force from the propeller due to gyroscopic precession. The force from the propeller will be rotated by 90º in the direction of rotation. In this case, the pitch-up will cause an forward force on the bottom of the propeller disc, which is rotated by precession to a forwards force on the right of the propeller disc. This creates a yaw to the left. Statement 2 is therefore incorrect. 3. SLIPSTREAM The spinning of the propeller affects the air that it pushes backwards, and imparts a spiral onto that air, in this case spiralling anti-clockwise around the aircraft, hitting the tail fin on the right hand side, causing a tail-left, nose-right moment. The slipstream increases with an increase in thrust, causing a yaw to the right. Statement 3 is correct. 4. ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT The asymmetric blade effect comes from the aircraft being at an angle of attack to the air, so the air does not flow perpendicular to the propeller disc. The down-going propeller blades always produce more thrust than the up-going blades, so the thrust line of this anti-clockwise propeller is to the left of centre. An increase in thrust will therefore cause a larger force through this location (left of centre), which yaws the aircraft to the right. Statement 4 is correct.

key_points: Gyroscopic precession manifests as a reaction when force is exerted on a gyroscope
In the context of a rotating propeller, this reaction occurs 90° in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force
Consequently, when an aircraft undergoes pitching or yawing movements, forces act upon the spinning propeller disc, leading to distinct reactions
learning.explanation: Gyroscopic precession manifests as a reaction when force is exerted on a gyroscope. In the context of a rotating propeller, this reaction occurs 90° in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. Consequently, when an aircraft undergoes pitching or yawing movements, forces act upon the spinning propeller disc, leading to distinct reactions. For instance, in an aircraft equipped with a clockwise rotating propeller, pitching the nose up applies a forward force to the bottom of the propeller disc. This force triggers a reaction 90° ahead in the rotation direction, resulting in a right yawing moment. The effects are as follows: Pitching down applies a forward force to the upper part of the disc, resulting in a force effect 90° clockwise and a left yaw. Yawing to the left applies a forward force to the right side, generating a force effect 90° clockwise and a pitch upward. Yawing to the right applies a forward force to the left side, producing a force effect 90° clockwise and a pitch downward.

The force developed by the engine and delivered to the propeller via the shaft is the rotational force of the propeller, the propeller torque. key_points: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage

The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect Gyroscopic Effect A rotating propeller has the properties of a gyroscope - rigidity in space and precession
The characteristic which produces “gyroscopic effect” is precession
learning.explanation: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage. The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect Gyroscopic Effect A rotating propeller has the properties of a gyroscope - rigidity in space and precession. The characteristic which produces “gyroscopic effect” is precession. Gyroscopic precession is the reaction that occurs when a force is applied to the rim of a rotating disc. When a force is applied to the rim of a propeller, the reaction occurs 90° ahead in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. As the aircraft is pitched up or down or yawed left or right, a force is applied to the rim of the spinning propeller disc. Gyroscopic effect only occurs when the aircraft pitches and/or yaws. The Gyroscopic Effect is more significant in situations of high power (RPM) and low forward speed, such as take-off or low speed climbs. Therefore, statement 1 is correct. For a clockwise rotating propeller: Pitch up - forward force on the bottom, force emerges 90° clockwise, right yaw. Right yaw - forward force on the left, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch down. Pitch down - forward force on the top, force emerges 90° clockwise, left yaw. Left yaw - forward force on the right, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch up.

key_points: In the event of an engine failure both the engine and the propeller will slow down
The CSU will attempt to maintain the selected RPM by driving the propeller blades to a fine position that will continue until reaching the fine pitch stop

Despite the engine failing the airplane still has forward speed, for a single-engine airplane due to the glide descent the forward speed causes the propeller to have a negative angle of attack due to the direction of the relative airflow
learning.explanation: In the event of an engine failure both the engine and the propeller will slow down. The CSU will attempt to maintain the selected RPM by driving the propeller blades to a fine position that will continue until reaching the fine pitch stop. Despite the engine failing the airplane still has forward speed, for a single-engine airplane due to the glide descent the forward speed causes the propeller to have a negative angle of attack due to the direction of the relative airflow. This angle of attack generates sufficient torque to rotate the unpowered propeller in the normal direction of rotation. The component of the force at right angles to the plane of rotation now acts rearwards and is no longer thrust but is now drag and presents a flat disc to the direction of travel. Because the propeller is being driven only by the relative airflow it is said to be wind milling. As such, it causes a considerable amount of drag, reduces the IAS, reduces the Lift/Drag ratio and increases the rate of descent.

content.question:
Considering the operation of a clockwise rotating propeller, complete the following sentences about propeller torque.
When the propeller is windmilling, propeller torque acts (1) _____. During negative pitch (reverse thrust) operation, propeller torque acts (2) _____.

options.A: (1) clockwise; (2) clockwise
options.B: (1) anti-clockwise; (2) anti-clockwise
options.C: (1) clockwise; (2) anti-clockwise
options.D: (1) anti-clockwise; (2) clockwise

key_points: The two aerodynamic forces acting on a propeller are similar to that of a wing, which has lift (what we want) and drag (what we don't want)
For a propeller though, these forces become Thrust (what we want) and Torque (what we don't want)
This torque is specifically propeller torque, which pushes back against the rotation of the engine, and thereby opposes engine torque
learning.explanation: The two aerodynamic forces acting on a propeller are similar to that of a wing, which has lift (what we want) and drag (what we don't want). For a propeller though, these forces become Thrust (what we want) and Torque (what we don't want). This torque is specifically propeller torque, which pushes back against the rotation of the engine, and thereby opposes engine torque. In normal operations, as in the first image above, the propeller torque is acting against the direction of rotation, so in this case, anti-clockwise. However, if the engine is windmilling, (second image) then there is no engine torque to rotate the propeller (usually because it has failed), however, the windmill effect means that the incoming airflow actually pushes the propeller the correct way round, which is clockwise in this case, and also produces a lot of negative thrust (drag). The aerodynamic propeller torque is therefore with the direction of rotation (clockwise), as it is the driving force, and strangely the engine drag is the opposing force (anti-clockwise) in this case. Therefore, the windmilling propeller torque direction is clockwise. Reverse thrust (negative pitch) operations are a whole other scenario (third image above). Often called the "beta range", this is where the propeller pitch is sent past the fine pitch stop and the angle of attack becomes very negative. The engine is still running the propeller at this point, often at high RPMs, as this negative angle of attack produces a lot of reverse thrust. The driving torque is still provided by the engine in this case though, and the propeller (aerodynamic) torque is opposing the direction of rotation, so even though the thrust produced is negative, the torques are still the same as normal operation. In this case, the propeller torque is anti-clockwise. Remember that a propeller is designed never to turn the wrong direction. If it is a clockwise rotating propeller, it will always want to turn clockwise. No scenario other than hand pulling will make it turn anticlockwise.

content.question: When on final approach to an airport in a single engine piston aircraft with a clockwise rotating propeller, the pilot anticipates that they may have to go around due to traffic still occupying the runway, so is thinking in advance how the aircraft will react. options.C: Yaw to the right; Roll to the right.

key_points: Note: This is similar to question 812009 but seen with more of a story in the question
Let's start by considering the roll of the aircraft, it is mainly just affected by the torque effect
TORQUE EFFECT This occurs primarily because the air resists the motion of the propeller
learning.explanation: Note: This is similar to question 812009 but seen with more of a story in the question. Let's start by considering the roll of the aircraft, it is mainly just affected by the torque effect. TORQUE EFFECT This occurs primarily because the air resists the motion of the propeller. In so doing, it tends to twist the engine and airframe in the opposite direction to the propeller (i.e. anti-clockwise). This causes the aircraft to roll to the left and is particularly noticeable in a go-around scenario, where the airspeed over the ailerons is low, and maximum power is applied, not only causing a large increase in torque effect but also the rotational acceleration of the propeller provides a further effect. So that's why the aircraft will roll to the left in this scenario. But the yaw is, unfortunately, a little more complicated as there are a few extra factors at play, in fact almost all the secondary effects are here. The asymmetric blade effect (P-factor) will cause a yaw to the left; The gyroscopic precession causes a smaller, temporary yaw to the right whilst pitching up; The slipstream effect causes an increased yaw to the left; and Therefore, overall the aircraft yaws to the left, hence the need for more right rudder than you expect if you've trained in an aircraft with a clockwise rotating propeller, which is highly likely. SLIPSTREAM The spinning of the propeller affects the air that it pushes backwards, and imparts a spiral onto that air, in this case spiralling clockwise around the aircraft, hitting the tail fin on the left hand side, causing a tail-right, nose-left moment. The slipstream increases with an increase in thrust, causing a yaw to the left. GYROSCOPIC PRECESSION The propeller is a mass, spinning at high speed, and therefore acts as a gyroscope. That means that any rotation of the aircraft in pitch or yaw will gain a different force from the propeller due to gyroscopic precession. The force from the propeller will be rotated by 90º in the direction of rotation. In this case, the pitch-up will cause a forward force on the bottom of the propeller disc, which is rotated by precession to a forwards force on the left of the propeller disc, which is a transient yaw to the right. ASYMMETRIC BLADE EFFECT The asymmetric blade effect comes from the aircraft being at an angle of attack to the air, so the air does not flow perpendicular to the propeller disc. The down-going propeller blades always produce more thrust than the up-going blades, due to a higher angle of attack, so the thrust line of this clockwise propeller is to the right of centre. An increase in thrust will therefore cause a larger force through this location (right of centre), which yaws the aircraft to the left.

content.question: Which of these statements concerning propellers is correct?

options.B: The blade angle of a feathered propeller is approximately 0 degrees.

key_points: To prevent the propeller from ‘wind milling’ the propeller blade is rotated from the fine-pitch stop through the coarse-pitch stop to reach the angle of attack to the relative airflow that produces zero lift; and referred to as ‘feathering’ the propeller
It’s usually approximately 85°/90° because it is the best compromise for the whole blade length and accounts for the blade twist

This blade position stops the propeller from rotating because there is no lift force to produce a torque reaction; it reduces the drag to a minimum level and prevents damage being caused to the engine
learning.explanation: To prevent the propeller from ‘wind milling’ the propeller blade is rotated from the fine-pitch stop through the coarse-pitch stop to reach the angle of attack to the relative airflow that produces zero lift; and referred to as ‘feathering’ the propeller. It’s usually approximately 85°/90° because it is the best compromise for the whole blade length and accounts for the blade twist. This blade position stops the propeller from rotating because there is no lift force to produce a torque reaction; it reduces the drag to a minimum level and prevents damage being caused to the engine. For a single-engine airplane feathering the propeller blades improves the glide performance because it does not require such a steep glide angle to maintain the required airspeed. As such, feathering the propeller increases the gliding range and endurance. For a multi-engine airplane, the decreased drag reduces the amount of thrust required to counteract the asymmetric force of the propeller of the failed engine and there is sufficient rudder authority remaining to enable the pilot to safely control the airplane.
