key_points: The critical engine of a multi-engine, fixed-wing propeller-driven aircraft is the one whose failure would result in the most adverse effects on the aircraft's handling and performance
When one of the engines on a typical multi-engine aircraft becomes inoperative, a thrust asymmetry exists
The thrust asymmetry can be different, depending on how the engine is mounted
learning.explanation: The critical engine of a multi-engine, fixed-wing propeller-driven aircraft is the one whose failure would result in the most adverse effects on the aircraft's handling and performance. When one of the engines on a typical multi-engine aircraft becomes inoperative, a thrust asymmetry exists. The thrust asymmetry can be different, depending on how the engine is mounted. Particularly on a propeller aircraft, the propellers are subject to the asymmetric blade effect, called P-factor. This occurs because the propeller does not spin perpendicular to the airflow, as the aircraft is flying with an angle of attack. This means that the down-going blades on the propeller have a higher angle of attack and longer track, so they produce more thrust. Therefore, the thrust vector of the engine is located not centrally, but more towards the down-going blade side. This means that one engine has its thrust vector further from the aircraft's longitudinal axis, and therefore if the other engine fails, it has a worse effect on yaw. This engine (with the worst effect on yaw) is called the critical engine. As the propellers on the pilot's new aircraft rotate anticlockwise (when viewed from behind), the down-going blades are on the left hand side, so the thrust lines of the engines are to the left of the engine. Therefore, losing the right hand engine would leave the pilot with the remaining thrust line furthest from the cockpit. The right hand engine is therefore the critical engine. Note that the figure shown above is the opposite, it is for an aircraft with clockwise rotating engines, as most do.

The rotation of a propeller creates a total reactive force at right angles to the chordline of the propeller blade. This can be divided into two components, that which is perpendicular to the relative airflow, the lift, and that which is parallel to the relative airflow, the drag. key_points: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage

The characteristic which produces “gyroscopic effect” is precession
learning.explanation: On take-off, rotation of a single-engine propeller causes an aircraft to swing to one side, particularly those fitted with a tail-dragger undercarriage. The main causes of this are: Slipstream effect Torque reaction Gyroscopic effect Asymmetric blade effect Gyroscopic Effect A rotating propeller has the properties of a gyroscope - rigidity in space and precession. The characteristic which produces “gyroscopic effect” is precession. Gyroscopic precession is the reaction that occurs when a force is applied to the rim of a rotating disc. When a force is applied to the rim of a propeller, the reaction occurs 90° ahead in the direction of rotation and in the same direction as the applied force. As the aircraft is pitched up or down or yawed left or right, a force is applied to the rim of the spinning propeller disc. Note: Gyroscopic effect only occurs when the aircraft pitches and/or yaws. For a clockwise rotating propeller: Pitch up - forward force on the bottom, force emerges 90° clockwise, right yaw. Right yaw - forward force on the left, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch down. Pitch down - forward force on the top, force emerges 90° clockwise, left yaw. Therefore, statement 1 is correct. Left yaw - forward force on the right, force emerges 90° clockwise, pitch up. Therefore, statement 2 is correct.

key_points: Short explanation: Counter-rotating propellers are employed not only to minimize the impact of p-factor but also as a secondary measure to diminish torque effects
The reduction in torque occurs through the configuration, for instance, when the propellers rotate inwards, with the left engine turning clockwise and the right engine turning anti-clockwise

learning.explanation: Short explanation: Counter-rotating propellers are employed not only to minimize the impact of p-factor but also as a secondary measure to diminish torque effects. The reduction in torque occurs through the configuration, for instance, when the propellers rotate inwards, with the left engine turning clockwise and the right engine turning anti-clockwise. In this setup, the torque effect generated by each engine is in the opposite direction, theoretically equal in magnitude. Consequently, the theoretical result is a reduction of the torque effect to zero. Further information: Most traditional twin-engine aircraft have clockwise-rotating propellers when viewed from behind. When equipped with co-rotating propellers (both rotating clockwise) on a small twin, there is minimal torque reaction around the airplane's center of gravity until one engine fails. A left turning tendency would then occur. In contrast, small twins with counter-rotating propellers can reduce torque reaction after an engine failure. In this configuration, the propeller on the left-hand engine (Engine nr.1) rotates clockwise, while the one on the right-hand engine (Engine nr.2) rotates counter-clockwise. The primary advantage lies in balancing torque and P-factor effects, ensuring there is no critical engine in the event of failure. The critical engine, in the context of a multi-engine airplane, refers to the engine whose failure would result in the most adverse impact on performance and handling abilities.

learning.explanation: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil. For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing. Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord. In case of positive camber, a wing will generate lift with airspeed, as the air on top of the airfoil will get accelerated more than on the bottom, creating a low pressure on the top and high pressure at the bottom. This is “pushing” the wing up into the air as the pressure difference wants to restore itself to 0 difference. In case of negative camber, the exact opposite happens and the lift coefficient for a certain speed is lower than for a positively cambered wing. A completely symmetrical airfoil will intersect the vertical axis of the graph at the origin (0). A positively cambered airfoil will generate more lift at the same speed (and therefore has a higher CL) than a symmetrical airfoil and therefore intersects the vertical axis above the origin. A negatively cambered airfoil will generate less lift at the same speed (which translates into a lower CL at a certain speed) and therefore intersects the vertical axis below the origin. The camber of an airfoil can be increased with the use of flaps. The end of the wing reaches out and/or downwards, changing the side profile of the wing and moving the CP aft, resulting in a nose down pitching moment. This generates a higher value of CL at the same Angle of Attack. Therefore if flaps are being retracted, the Angle of Attack should be increased.

key_points: When density altitude decreases, the air gets "thicker", meaning that there are more air particles per cubic metre, and therefore more air particles will hit our aircraft and flow over its wings per mile flown
This would increase lift and drag if we were trying to maintain the same TAS
However, to counteract this effect, we fly our aircraft at a constant IAS/CAS (Indicated Airspeed/Calibrated Airspeed), which is a simple measure of dynamic pressure
learning.explanation: When density altitude decreases, the air gets "thicker", meaning that there are more air particles per cubic metre, and therefore more air particles will hit our aircraft and flow over its wings per mile flown. This would increase lift and drag if we were trying to maintain the same TAS. However, to counteract this effect, we fly our aircraft at a constant IAS/CAS (Indicated Airspeed/Calibrated Airspeed), which is a simple measure of dynamic pressure. This value measures the amount of air particles hitting the aircraft, and their speed. If we fly at a constant IAS, but descend in the atmosphere, the higher air density means that we have to fly slower to get the same amount of dynamic pressure, meaning the same amount of air particles over the wing, etc. This is a decrease in TAS (True Airspeed) for a constant IAS. IAS directly controls our drag and our lift, as they vary proportionally to dynamic pressure, see the lift or drag equation for the mathematical proof here, it is very easy to spot. D = (1/2 x ρ x V2)x CD x S As dynamic pressure is 1/2 x ρ x V2, which is measured by the IAS, then drag is directly proportional to IAS, coefficient of drag, and surface area. If the graph was for total drag against IAS, then the curve would remain in exactly the same position with decreased altitude. As the X-axis on the graphs is TAS, not IAS, then with a decrease in altitude, the drag curve will look the same, but will be shifted to the left, due to the decreased TAS for the same IAS at lower altitudes, but as the same forces of drag exist at each point on the curve, the curve will not move up or down. The answer is therefore figure 2, moving to the left.

options.B: Angle of attack increases; margin to stall reduces.

learning.explanation: IMPORTANT NOTE: The feedback for this question is old and has not been verified for over a year. Given other questions in the database which have been confirmed, we have decided to change the options to make one "actually correct", rather than the very questionable previous options, which were never fully verified. This question could have even been removed from EASA's database by now, but we also cannot guarantee that. Please let us know in the comments if you see this question in the real exam, and anything you can remember from it. BACKGROUND INFORMATION Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons. They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift. (If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions). They are called spoilers because they "spoil" the airflow, sticking up into the airflow, causing a lift reduction similar to an up-going aileron and a similar drag increase to that of a split flap. Of course, the spoiled airflow is not as effective at producing lift, and the CLMAX of wings with spoilers extended is much lower, so the stall speed therefore increases. The effect of spoilers on the critical angle of attack is much more complex (and explained where necessary in different questions), and unpredictable, but EASA appear to say that it increases with spoiler deployment (opposite to how it decreases when trailing edge flaps are deployed). As far as we are aware, it could actually increase or decrease slightly in real life, dependent on the wing, spoiler size and location, and particularly the amount of spoiler extension. For this question though, mercifully, the answer remains the same. ANSWERING THE QUESTION The question asks about the angle of attack of the wing. When spoilers are extended, the lift decreases, so without any change to the angle of attack, then the aircraft will no longer be in equilibrium, so in reality, to counteract weight, the angle of attack of the wing has to increase. This agrees with our experience of flying jets, in when we extend spoilers, the aircraft pitches up slightly. The margin to the stall is a very vague term, as it could mean the difference between current speed and stall speed, but it is more likely to mean in terms of angle of attack, and in this case, would probably be the difference between the aircraft's current angle of attack and the critical angle of attack (AoA). When spoilers are extended, the actual AoA is forced to increase to maintain the flight path, and the critical angle of attack will either decrease slightly (according to some other sources) or increase slightly (according to EASA's other questions), but either way, the increase in current AoA will likely be much greater, so the margin to stall will decrease.

The mass air flow 'm' is the product of the density, the area and the velocity: m= ρ*A*V Continuity equation: m1= m2= m3= ρ1* A1* V1= ρ2* A2* V2= ρ3* A3* V3=constant The continuity equation explains the relationship between velocity and cross-sectional area: The speed is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area. Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem) The total energy of an airstream comes in two forms: potential energy (static pressure) and kinetic energy (dynamic pressure). The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy. Thus, an increase in one form of pressure, must result in a decrease in the other. Dynamic pressure (q) is expressed by: q= 1/2* ρ* V2 Assuming the total pressure to be constant, the static pressure and the dynamic pressure vary inversely: If one increases the other decreases and vice-versa. As an airfoil (wing) moves through the air, varying changes in velocity occur on its surfaces. Air particles move around it in specific trajectories. These trajectories are called streamlines. Diverging streamlines mean a decrease in airspeed. Converging streamlines imply an increase in airspeed. In Conclusion: With an increase in section area (from station 2 to station 3), flow speed decreases, decreasing dynamic pressure (streamlines diverge). If dynamic pressure decreases, static pressure increases. Statement 1 is therefore incorrect. With an increase in section area (from station 2 to station 3), flow speed decreases, decreasing dynamic pressure (streamlines diverge). Statement 2 is therefore incorrect.

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
It acts in the direction of the relative wind
Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. It acts in the direction of the relative wind. Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed (with a rate of 1/V2) and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again.

key_points: Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons
They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift
(If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions)
learning.explanation: Spoilers are aerodynamic surfaces that exist on the top surface of some wings, and are used for many reasons. They are primarily used to increase drag and "dump" lift. (If they are just for drag then they are called speedbrakes, but aircraft manufacturers do blur these distinctions). They are called spoilers because they "spoil" the airflow, sticking up into the airflow, causing a lift reduction similar to an up-going aileron and a similar drag increase to that of a split flap. Of course, the spoiled airflow is not as effective at producing lift, and the CLMAX of wings with spoilers extended is much lower, so the stall speed therefore increases. The effect on the critical angle of attack is much more complicated, however, and is not always easy to predict. As the spoiler pushes up into the airflow, the adverse pressure gradient over it (which usually causes the stall) is reduced and the airflow is re-energised, but the area behind the spoiler (most do not go all the way to the trailing edge of the wing) is automatically stalled after a small spoiler deflection, due to the gap created. So there are two opposing forces at play: Spoilers act a little bit like an up-going aileron, re-energising the airflow and increasing the critical AoA, The large stalled area behind the spoiler decreases the lift of the wing greatly, with an unknown effect on the critical AoA Therefore, it is difficult to say what effect spoiler deflection will have on the critical AoA. Some sources mention a slight decrease in critical AoA overall, but it appears that EASA have published other questions where the overall effect is an increase in the critical AoA due to spoiler extension, so we have stuck with this across all questions, as it seems likely that the examiner wants this answer (and feedback has agreed with this in the past). Of course, the real answer is certain to depend on the proportion of the wing, the size and location of the spoiler, and most importantly, the amount of spoiler deflection. As this is so complex, the examiner’s choice of answer is all that truly matters here. A big consideration for this question is the scenario. We are at the critical AoA and we raise the speedbrakes. Of course, we will begin to descend as the drag increases, unless we add thrust. if we don't do either of these things then the aircraft will quickly stall, but initially, assuming the angle of attack remains constant, the speedbrake extension should slightly delay the stall to a higher AoA.

key_points: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight)

learning.explanation: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speed brakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight). The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag. The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag. This speed is called Minimum Drag Speed (VMD). Flying at a slower or faster speed than VMD will generate more drag. Flying at a slower speed than VMD (back side), the aircraft will be in the unstable speed region. Any loss of speed will result in an increase in drag and further speed loss (which must be corrected by an increase in thrust). content.question: Which statement concerning the local flow pattern around a wing is correct?

options.A: By fitting winglets to the wing tip, the strength of the wing tip vortices is reduced which in turn reduces induced drag.
options.B: Slat extension, at a constant angle of attack and normal extension speeds, will increase the lift coefficient, which will also increase the induced drag coefficient.
options.C: Sweepback reduces drag since, compared with a straight wing of equal area, the span increases.
options.D: Vortex generators on the wing partially block the spanwise flow over the wing leading to a reduction in induced drag.

key_points: "By fitting winglets to the wing tip, the strength of the wingtip vortices is reduced, which in turn reduces induced drag
" Correct
Winglets are small vertical aerofoils that are integrated into the wingtip
learning.explanation: "By fitting winglets to the wing tip, the strength of the wingtip vortices is reduced, which in turn reduces induced drag." Correct. Winglets are small vertical aerofoils that are integrated into the wingtip. These generate a slight forward force and disrupt the airflow from the lower to the upper surface of the wing, diminishing the intensity of the wingtip vortex. Both effects contribute to a reduction in induced drag. Let's examine the remaining options and discuss why they are incorrect: "Slat extension, at a constant angle of attack and normal extension speeds, will increase the lift coefficient, which will also increase the induced drag coefficient." Incorrect. At a constant aircraft angle of attack, the extension of slats decreases the angle of attack on the specific wing section, preventing an increase in the lift coefficient (CL). The advantage of slats becomes evident when the aircraft's angle of attack is subsequently increased. "Sweepback reduces drag since, compared with a straight wing of equal area, the span increases." Incorrect. Sweepback actually reduces the wingspan, thereby lowering the aspect ratio and increasing induced drag. "Vortex generators on the wing partially block the spanwise flow over the wing, leading to a reduction in induced drag." Incorrect. Vortex generators are designed to energize the boundary layer, but they typically contribute to increased drag rather than inducing a reduction in induced drag.

key_points: A venturi works on the principle of pressure, speed and airflow
Air comes in under constant pressure (which we will call X from this point onwards) and is directed through the tube
At a certain point in time, the tube starts becoming tighter
learning.explanation: A venturi works on the principle of pressure, speed and airflow. Air comes in under constant pressure (which we will call X from this point onwards) and is directed through the tube. At a certain point in time, the tube starts becoming tighter. However, the same amount of air still has to travel through this (now tighter) tube (we call this airflow Y). It does so by flowing faster than before. This increased airspeed creates a lower pressure at the tighter part of the venturi, while the wider part still has its original pressure and airspeed. After the tightening, the tube becomes wider again and the air returns to its original static pressure and airspeed (airflow Z). It now has the properties of airflow X again. Before the venturi (airflow X) Static Pressure normal Speed of the airflow normal In the throat (airflow Y) Total pressure same as airflow X and Z Static Pressure low Speed of the airflow increased After the venturi (airflow Z) Static Pressure normal Speed of the airflow normal The venturi works on Bernoulli’s principle. Bernoulli’s principle states that in increase in speed of a fluid occurs simultaneously with a decrease in the fluid’s static pressure. The formula for this principle = Total pressure = static pressure + dynamic pressure. If airspeed increases, the static pressure decreases and dynamic pressure increases, keeping total pressure the same.

Induced drag increases. Downwash increases. Therefore, the lift decreases when leaving ground effect, and this is more prominent on a low-wing aeroplane where the wings are naturally much closer to the ground.

content.question: When comparing the effectiveness of leading edge (LE) flaps and trailing edge (TE) flaps in reducing an aircraft's stall speed, which statement is correct?

options.A: Leading edge flaps reduce stall speed more effectively than trailing edge flaps because they enhance the wing’s curvature, increasing lift at lower speeds.
options.B: Trailing edge flaps reduce stall speed more effectively than leading edge flaps by increasing the wing area and camber, enhancing lift.
options.C: Both leading edge and trailing edge flaps have the same effect on reducing stall speed by equally increasing the wing's lift capabilities.
options.D: Neither leading edge nor trailing edge flaps significantly reduce the stall speed; they primarily affect the aircraft's drag.

key_points: Important Note: This was fed back to us without the correct answer being known
In this form, the options are quite vague and we could discuss which is correct for a long time and likely never reach an answer
Therefore, we have used our experience with the authorities to give our "best guess" of their correct answer
learning.explanation: Important Note: This was fed back to us without the correct answer being known. In this form, the options are quite vague and we could discuss which is correct for a long time and likely never reach an answer. Therefore, we have used our experience with the authorities to give our "best guess" of their correct answer. Obviously, the question could well be better worded in the real exam and with good knowledge of this subject, would likely be much easier to answer. Please do let us know if you see this question in the exam, any differences you noticed from our version, and if you have any idea of the correct answer with your exam authority, thank you! Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances and improve slow flying characteristics. There are both leading edge devices (LE flaps, kreuger flaps and slats) and trailing edge high lift devices (TE flaps of many kinds). Their primary purpose is to allow the aircraft to fly slower, and they do this by increasing the CLMAX of the wings, so that the lift will be enough to counteract weight, even at lower airspeeds. The greater the CLMAX becomes, the lower the stall speed. Secondary effects are increased drag and a change to the wing's chord line and angle of incidence, allowing the aircraft to fly with different pitch attitudes, which can be useful for pilot vision during landing. Let's go through the options now. "Leading edge flaps reduce stall speed more effectively than trailing edge flaps because they enhance the wing’s curvature, increasing lift at lower speeds." This is not strictly true. Whilst leading edge flaps do enhance the wing's curvature, so do trailing edge flaps, and they both increase the maximum available lift at all speeds. "Trailing edge flaps reduce stall speed more effectively than leading edge flaps by increasing the wing area and camber, enhancing lift." This is also very difficult to justify, as their increase in CLMAX depends on the TE/LE flaps used and to what degree. Also, not all flaps increase the wing area, only fowler flaps and some variations upon them. Again, TE and LE flaps both increase CLMAX. "Both leading edge and trailing edge flaps have the same effect on reducing stall speed by equally increasing the wing's lift capabilities." For us, this seems most likely to be correct. They both reduce the stall speed by increasing the lifting capability of the wing, allowing the aircraft to fly slower before stalling. "Equally" is a bad word to use though, as they could definitely have a different amount of effect, but it is not for us to say if they do, or which is most "useful". "Neither leading edge nor trailing edge flaps significantly reduce the stall speed; they primarily affect the aircraft's drag." Obviously incorrect, as they both do significantly reduce the stall speed.

options.B: increases stall speed.

key_points: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag
This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient
If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices
learning.explanation: Wing tip vortices increase if we increase induced drag. This can be caused by for example increased speed, density or lift coefficient. If we increase Angle of Attack, lift will be increased, also increasing the strength of wing tip vortices. Another factor increasing wing tip vortices is the aspect ratio (λ) of the wing. This is the ratio of the wing span to its mean chord. The aspect ratio of the wing is equal to the square of the wingspan divided by the wing surface area. Therefore a short but wide wing has a low aspect ratio but a long, narrow wing has a high aspect ratio. With a lower aspect ratio, the induced drag is higher, thus increasing wing tip vortices. With a high aspect ratio, the induced drag is lower, reducing wing tip vortices. We can therefore state that the relationship between wing tip vortices and aspect ratio is inversely proportional.

key_points: Lets consider both the take off and landing situations: Take off and climb – The aircraft will be flying close to its stall speed, so we want to increase our maximum angle of attack and therefore have a bigger margin of safety in case of windshear or engine failures
At the same time, we want good performance to climb out clear of obstacles
Since the climb angle is based on thrust and drag: Sin (γ) = (T – D) / W We know that we need to minimize drag as much as possible to get the best climb performance
learning.explanation: Lets consider both the take off and landing situations: Take off and climb – The aircraft will be flying close to its stall speed, so we want to increase our maximum angle of attack and therefore have a bigger margin of safety in case of windshear or engine failures. At the same time, we want good performance to climb out clear of obstacles. Since the climb angle is based on thrust and drag: Sin (γ) = (T – D) / W We know that we need to minimize drag as much as possible to get the best climb performance. Therefore lower flaps will be used. High flaps setting usually provide only a slight increase in lift whilst adding a large amount of drag. Approach and landing – The aircraft will be flying again at slow speeds, therefore to increase the safety margin we want a higher CLMAX and therefore a slower stall speed. Secondly, we are in a descent, therefore we can afford to have much more drag than during the departure. Therefore we use a large flap setting which will also create high levels of drag.

learning.explanation: Flaps are called high-lift devices, and are primarily used to allow an aircraft to fly slower without stalling, useful for take-off and landing. Their other uses are for increased drag; modern jet aeroplanes are particularly "slippery" these days, and sometimes struggle to lose energy, so flaps can be used to help with this. Flaps also change the chord line of the wing, allowing a more nose-down attitude for better pilot visibility and easier landings. Flaps increase lift by increasing the camber of the wing, and often also increasing the wing area, depending on the style of flaps. This helps the aircraft gain more lift for the same airflow. An aircraft only needs enough lift to counteract its own weight in normal operations (and a little more in turns), so there is no need for more lift, only to fly slower, with the same amount of lift. The increased drag also comes from the increased camber and wing area, as this makes the wing less efficient, with a lower lift-to-drag ratio. The steeper the flap angle, the higher the drag they will produce, and this is parasite drag, which increases with the square of the speed. content.question: Consider an aircraft flying in unaccelerated level flight in the speed stable region. How does the drag change following a sudden increase in CAS with no change in thrust available, and what will happen to the airspeed after this?

options.A: The total drag increases and the airspeed will decrease.
options.B: The total drag increases and the airspeed will further increase.
options.C: The induced drag increases and the airspeed will remain the same.
options.D: The parasite drag decreases and the airspeed will further increase.

key_points: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speedbrakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight)
The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag
The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag
learning.explanation: During flight, an aircraft will experience two types of drag: - Parasite Drag (proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing “Parasite Area”: flaps, undercarriage or speedbrakes) - Induced Drag (inversely proportional to IAS2, increases with increasing weight). The sum of Parasite Drag and Induced Drag is the Total Drag. The Total Drag will be minimum at the IAS where Parasite Drag = Induced Drag. This speed is called Minimum Drag Speed (VMD). Flying at a slower or faster speed than VMD will generate more drag. Flying at a slower speed than VMD (back side), the aircraft will be in the unstable speed region. Any gain of speed will result in an decrease in drag and further speed increase. The sudden change to a headwind (or a decrease in tailwind) can cause a gain of airspeed. Flying at a faster speed than VMD (front side), the aircraft will be in the stable speed region. Any increase of speed will result in an increase in drag. This increase in drag will cause the speed to decrease again (unless the thrust has changed). Therefore, a sudden increase in CAS, due to something like an increase in headwind (or a decrease in tailwind) can cause a momentary increase of airspeed, which eventually recues back to the original airspeed.

options.B: A dimensionless quantity that is used to quantify the resistance of an object applied by moving against a solid.

key_points: The coefficient of drag is a generic measure of the amount of drag exerted on an object in a particular fluid flow
It is not a force, it simply dictates "how draggy" an object (a wing or aircraft in our case) is
There are a few technical definitions for it, each one is correct, and explains it in a different way
learning.explanation: The coefficient of drag is a generic measure of the amount of drag exerted on an object in a particular fluid flow. It is not a force, it simply dictates "how draggy" an object (a wing or aircraft in our case) is. There are a few technical definitions for it, each one is correct, and explains it in a different way. To understand it, you must know that it is a way of comparing two objects, and how much drag force acts on them, for a specific size and dynamic pressure. The actual drag force is calculated by the formula D = 1/2 x ρ x V2 x CD x S where D = Drag (N) V = True Airspeed (m/s) CD = Coefficient of Drag S = Wing Area (surface area) (m2) The coefficient of drag is dimensionless, it has no units. One of its definitions is as follows, "The Drag Coefficient (CD) is a dimensionless number that is used to quantify the resistance of an object as it moves through a fluid.", as eluded to by this question.

Flaps increase the camber of the wing, and sometimes extend backwards to increase the wing are too
learning.explanation: Flaps are high-lift devices, primarily used to allow flight at slower airspeeds for take-off and landing. Flaps also increase aircraft drag, which can be useful for energy management, particularly on large jets. Flaps increase the camber of the wing, and sometimes extend backwards to increase the wing are too. Increasing the camber leads to an increased coefficient of lift (CL), which allows a higher lift force to be produced from the same airflow. This means that an aircraft can fly slower without stalling, as the same amount of lift required to balance out the aircraft weight will be created at lower indicated air speeds. We do not use flaps all the time because they also greatly increase the coefficient of drag (CD), but this is not the answer to the question as increased drag is just a side effect, and does not allow us to fly slower without stalling.

content.question: Which of the following wing planforms produces the lowest induced drag? (assume zero wing twist)

options.A: Tapered.
options.B: Elliptical.
options.C: Rectangular.
options.D: Circular.

key_points: INDUCED DRAG Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips
The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centre-line of the aircraft
It is the production of lift itself which reduces the magnitude of the lift force being generated
learning.explanation: INDUCED DRAG Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips. The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centre-line of the aircraft. It is the production of lift itself which reduces the magnitude of the lift force being generated. To replace the lift lost by the increased downwash, the aircraft must be flown at a higher angle of attack. This increases drag. This extra drag is called induced drag. The stronger the vortices, the greater the induced drag. The main factors affecting induced drag are wing planform, aspect ratio, speed, and weight/lift. The effect of planform is the principal factor affecting induced drag. The size of the wing tip vortex is directly related to the length of the wing tip chord. A rectangular planform wing produces a much larger vortex than the tapered section. This is because the longer the tip chord, the greater the spillage of air from the lower surface onto the upper surface, and the larger the wing tip vortex. In aerodynamic terms, the elliptical planform wing is the most aerodynamically efficient because the downwash remains constant across the complete wingspan, giving minimal induced drag.

CLMAX AUGMENTATION One of the main factors which determine the CLMAX of an aerofoil section is the camber
Increasing the camber of an aerofoil section increases the CL at a given angle of attack and increases CLMAX
learning.explanation: Aircraft are fitted with high lift devices to reduce the take-off and landing distances. CLMAX AUGMENTATION One of the main factors which determine the CLMAX of an aerofoil section is the camber. Increasing the camber of an aerofoil section increases the CL at a given angle of attack and increases CLMAX. An increase in CLMAX will reduce the stall speed. LEADING EDGE SLAT A slat is a small auxiliary aerofoil attached to the leading edge of the wing. When deployed, the slat forms a slot which allows passage of air from the high pressure region below the wing to the low pressure region above it. Kinetic Energy is added to the airflow through the slot by the slat forming a convergent duct. When slats are deployed, the boundary layer is re-energized. The effect of the slat is to prolong the lift curve by delaying boundary layer separation until a higher angle of attack. The magnitude of the increase to CLMAX and the extent of the decrease to the stalling speed are directly proportional to the length of the leading edge of the aerofoil covered by the slat and the chord of the slat itself, i.e. the longer the slat the greater the CLMAX and the lower the stalling speed.

content.question: What will happen to the stall speed, stalling Angle Of Attack (AOA) and controllability of an aircraft in flight due to icing?

options.B: Stall speed will increase but stalling AOA and controllability will both decrease.
options.C: Stall speed will decrease but stalling AOA and controllability will both increase.
options.D: Stall speed, stalling AOA and controllability will all increase.

key_points: Stalling angle of attack: as ice builds up, the aerodynamic efficiency of the wing and its ability to prevent separation of the airflow and therefore stall is highly reduced
Ice will lead to sooner separation, smaller stalling angle of attack, therefore causing a lower CLMAX
Stall speed: referring to the lift equation, and assuming all other factors stay the same, ice buildup decreases the CLMAX and increases the mass of the aircraft in flight
learning.explanation: Stalling angle of attack: as ice builds up, the aerodynamic efficiency of the wing and its ability to prevent separation of the airflow and therefore stall is highly reduced. Ice will lead to sooner separation, smaller stalling angle of attack, therefore causing a lower CLMAX. Stall speed: referring to the lift equation, and assuming all other factors stay the same, ice buildup decreases the CLMAX and increases the mass of the aircraft in flight. Firstly just by itself an increase in mass causes an increase in stall speed. Secondly, a smaller CLMAX means that a higher speed will have to be maintained in order to maintain the same lift. Therefore our stall speed will have increase due to ice accretion. Controllability: on top of the fact that an increase in weight will mean that any input in the control surfaces will lead to a slower reaction by the aircraft, icing can also get stuck between the control surfaces and or completely nullify their effect. For example, icing on the horizontal stabilizer will occur before the main wing, and seeing as the tail is normally producing a downwards force, a stall of the tail plane will lead to a drop of the nose of the aircraft and controllability over the longitudinal axis will have been completely lost. Therefore controllability will decrease in icing conditions.

content.question:
Given a constant load factor, which of these statements about the variation of induced drag with changes of speed and mass are correct or incorrect?
1. When speed increases, induced drag decreases.
2. When mass increases, induced drag increases.

options.A: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.
options.B: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.C: 1 is incorrect, 2 is incorrect.
options.D: 1 is correct, 2 is correct.

key_points: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift
The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing
This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag
learning.explanation: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift. The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing. This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag. This question is asking for the effect of: Speed: The induced drag is inversely proportional to the speed. Therefore, induced drag increases as the speed decreases, and, induced drag decreases and the speed increases. This is because, to maintain lift constant, as the velocity decreases, the coefficient of lift will have to be increased. At higher coefficients of lift, the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing will be greater and therefore produce stronger vortices = stronger induced drag. (and vice versa) Changing mass: Induced drag is proportional to the mass. Therefore, induced drag increases with increasing aeroplane mass, and, induced drag decreases with decreasing aeroplane mass. This is because, as the aircraft get heavier, the lift that the wings will have to produce increases. To achieve that, the coefficient of lift will have to increase, meaning a higher AoA, which creates stronger vortices. (and vice versa) Summary: Higher AR = Lower induced drag Higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher weight = higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher speed = lower AoA = lower induced drag Winglets = lower induced drag.

learning.explanation: The pitching moment is the force that causes an aeroplane to move about its lateral axis. The force in this case is the lift and is applied through the CP. The arm is the distance of the CP from a specified position. As the CP moves with the changing angle of attack, the moment about a point will also change as the angle of attack changes. On a cambered aerofoil even though the centre of pressure (CP) moves with the changing angle of attack, the lift is assumed to act through the aerodynamic centre (AC). The combination of the AC and the pitching moment coefficient are required for the analysis of the longitudinal stability of an aeroplane. The tailplane is a major contributor to the longitudinal stability of an aeroplane. To maintain a particular angle of attack a specific deflection of the elevator is established that will maintain this requirement. Thus, the movement of CP has an effect on both the pitching moment and stabilizer movement.

key_points: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together
It acts in the direction of the relative wind
Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind
learning.explanation: The total drag is the resulting factor if you add induced drag and parasite drag together. It acts in the direction of the relative wind. Lift is perpendicular to the relative wind. Parasite drag is caused if an airfoil is moving through the air. It is the result of form drag and skin friction drag. Form drag arises from the shape of the object. The more streamlined the object, the less form drag is present. Shape and size are most important in the amount of form drag resulting. Form drag increases with increasing velocity, making it very important for high speed aircraft. Skin friction drag is caused by the friction of the fluid (in case of aircraft this fluid is the atmosphere) against the skin of the object moving through it. It is directly related to the surface area in contact with the fluid. Skin friction increases with the square of the velocity. Induced drag is caused when an object redirects the airflow. A wing produces lift by creating a pressure difference. This pressure difference is caused by the shape of the airfoil, causing the airflow on top to accelerate, creating a low pressure on top of the wing and high pressure below the wing. This pressure difference naturally wants to restore towards a uniform pressure, which creates vortices around the wingtip. These vortices are deflected downwards, this phenomenon is also called downwash. The induced drag decreases with airspeed (with a rate of 1/V²) and increases with angle of attack and increasing weight. In the image we can see that the two vectors (induced and parasite drag) create a resulting vector, the total drag. Where the induced and parasite drag vectors collide, we have the minimum drag speed (VMD); the speed where the total drag is the lowest. This leads us to understand that during an acceleration from a total stand still, the total drag first decreases up until the minimum drag speed and then starts increasing again.

key_points: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift
The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing
This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag
learning.explanation: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift. The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing. This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag. This question is asking for the effect of: Speed: The induced drag is inversely proportional to the speed. Therefore, induced drag increases as the speed decreases, and, induced drag decreases and the speed increases. This is because, to maintain lift constant, as the velocity decreases, the coefficient of lift will have to be increased. At higher coefficients of lift, the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing will be greater and therefore produce stronger vortices = stronger induced drag. (and vice versa) Changing mass: Induced drag is proportional to the mass. Therefore, induced drag increases with increasing aeroplane mass, and, induced drag decreases with decreasing aeroplane mass. This is because, as the aircraft get heavier, the lift that the wings will have to produce increases. To achieve that, the coefficient of lift will have to increase, meaning a higher AoA, which creates stronger vortices. (and vice versa) Summary: Higher AR = Lower induced drag Higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher weight = higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher speed = lower AoA = lower induced drag Winglets = lower induced drag.

content.question: The lift force, acting on an aerofoil: (no flow separation)

options.A: is mainly caused by reduced pressure on the upper surface.
options.B: is mainly caused by overpressure at the underside of the aerofoil.
options.C: increases, proportional to the angle of attack until 40 degrees.
options.D: is maximum at an angle of attack of 2 degrees.

key_points: A plane can remain in the air by the wings generating lift
If this lift is equal to the weight (and the aircraft is in the air), the aircraft will remain in level flight
A wing operates through the principle of pressure differential and equal and opposite reactions
learning.explanation: A plane can remain in the air by the wings generating lift. If this lift is equal to the weight (and the aircraft is in the air), the aircraft will remain in level flight. A wing operates through the principle of pressure differential and equal and opposite reactions. An aerofoil segment can generate lift by either having an angle of attack to the relative airflow, or but being cambered (bulging more in one direction), or both. Both these things mean that, to create lift upwards, the air flowing over the top of the wing must travel faster than the air underneath the wing, in order to provide a low pressure area above the wing due to the venturi effect. The way this occurs can be thought of through many different approaches, but it is easiest for our purposes just to say that the streamlines of air going over the wing get squashed together more than those under the wing (there is a little more to it, but we don't want to make it any more complex). The venturi effect creates a low pressure area above the wing, and the relatively higher pressure beneath the wing means that there is a net force upwards on the wing (from high to low), which is our lift. The air behind the wing is also given some downwash by this effect, and that satisfies the "equal and opposite forces" of Newton's 3rd law, in that the air going downwards forces the aircraft to go upwards. It is important to know that the low pressure air is the main contributor to the lifting effect, and not the "high" pressure beneath the wing, as that is only high relative to the low, not relative to ambient pressure.

options.C: Increase the camber of the aerofoil and increase the effective angle of attack, so that CLMAX is reached at higher angles of attack.
options.D: Decrease the boundary layer energy and decrease the suction peak on the slat, so that CLMAX is reached at lower angles of attack.

key_points: Slats are aerodynamic surfaces on the leading edge of the wings
When deployed, the slat forms a slot which allows passage of air from the high pressure region below the wing to the low pressure region above it
Additional Kinetic Energy is added to the airflow through the slot by the slat forming a convergent duct
learning.explanation: Slats are aerodynamic surfaces on the leading edge of the wings. When deployed, the slat forms a slot which allows passage of air from the high pressure region below the wing to the low pressure region above it. Additional Kinetic Energy is added to the airflow through the slot by the slat forming a convergent duct. When slats are deployed the boundary layer is re-energised. If Kinetic Energy is added to the boundary layer, boundary layer separation will be delayed to a much higher angle of attack. In terms of the pressure distribution of the aerofoil with a slat extended, the slat provides a fair amount of lift itself due to its shape, and when extended, it flattens the peak of the low pressure zone somewhat, allowing the low pressure zone to be more evenly distributed over the top of the aerofoil. It increases the suction overall as it allows a much higher critical AoA and higher CLMAX, as the adverse pressure gradient occurs more gradually, delaying the stall. Furthermore, the suction peak flattens, it does not move. This is why the CL location does not change very much when extending flaps. Note: We are aware that the wording of the correct option here is a little off regarding the suction peak, as the peak should reduce, but the overall suction increases. We think this could be what the examiner is trying to say. We still think it is the most correct option by far out of the available options, but please send us any further feedback if you see this question in the exam, thank you!

This reduces the wing's stalling angle of attack and also its maximum coefficient of lift by up to 50%. Critical Angle of Attack Increased surface friction results in quicker flow separation. This reduces the critical angle of attack and a stall will occur sooner. key_points: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil
For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing
Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord
learning.explanation: Camber is the asymmetry between two acting surfaces on an airfoil. For an aircraft, this is the top and the bottom of the wing. Positive camber means that a wing is thicker on the top end of the wing, than on the bottom if looked at from the chord. In case of positive camber, a wing will generate lift with airspeed, as the air on top of the airfoil will get accelerated more than on the bottom, creating a low pressure on the top and high pressure at the bottom. This is “pushing” the wing up into the air as the pressure difference wants to restore itself to 0 difference. In case of negative camber, the exact opposite happens and the lift coefficient for a certain speed is lower than for a positively cambered wing. A completely symmetrical airfoil will intersect the vertical axis of the graph at the origin (0). A positively cambered airfoil will generate more lift at the same speed (and therefore has a higher CL) than a symmetrical airfoil and therefore intersects the vertical axis above the origin. A negatively cambered airfoil will generate less lift at the same speed (which translates into a lower CL at a certain speed) and therefore intersects the vertical axis below the origin. The camber of an airfoil can be increased with the use of flaps. The end of the wing reaches out and/or downwards, changing the side profile of the wing and moving the CP aft, resulting in a nose down pitching moment. This generates a higher value of CL at the same Angle of Attack. Therefore if flaps are being retracted, the Angle of Attack should be increased.

Given a constant load factor, which of these statements about the variation of induced drag with changes of speed and mass are correct or incorrect?

options.A: 1 is correct, 2 is incorrect.
options.B: 1 is incorrect, 2 is correct.

key_points: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift
The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing
This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag
learning.explanation: Induced drag is created as a byproduct of lift. The pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing creates a upwash around the tip of the wing that turns into a downwash behind the wing. This is known as a vortex, which creates a rearward force known as induced drag. This question is asking for the effect of: Speed: The induced drag is inversely proportional to the speed. Therefore, induced drag increases as the speed decreases, and, induced drag decreases and the speed increases. This is because, to maintain lift constant, as the velocity decreases, the coefficient of lift will have to be increased. At higher coefficients of lift, the pressure differential between the top and bottom of the wing will be greater and therefore produce stronger vortices = stronger induced drag. (and vice versa) Changing mass: Induced drag is proportional to the mass. Therefore, induced drag increases with increasing aeroplane mass, and, induced drag decreases with decreasing aeroplane mass. This is because, as the aircraft get heavier, the lift that the wings will have to produce increases. To achieve that, the coefficient of lift will have to increase, meaning a higher AoA, which creates stronger vortices. (and vice versa) Summary: Higher AR = Lower induced drag Higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher weight = higher AoA = higher induced drag Higher speed = lower AoA = lower induced drag Winglets = lower induced drag.

learning.explanation: Aspect ratio The aspect ratio of the wing closely affects the aerodynamic characteristics and structural strength/weight of a wing. Typical aspect ratios vary from 35 for a high-performance sailplane to as low as 3 for a jet fighter. The aspect ratio of a modern high-speed jet transport is about 12. content.question:

The figure shows a polar diagram of CL vs CD. Extending which of the following devices would cause the line to move from position 1 to position 2?

options.A: Flaps.
options.B: Landing Gear.
options.C: Lift dumpers.
options.D: Slats.

key_points: The polar diagram of CL vs CD is a very common one to be used in the exams
It takes every angle of attack of the wing, and plots the corresponding CL and CD values as a point on the graph
It is not as easy to read as a standard graph, but once you get used to that, it becomes quite simple
learning.explanation: The polar diagram of CL vs CD is a very common one to be used in the exams. It takes every angle of attack of the wing, and plots the corresponding CL and CD values as a point on the graph. It is not as easy to read as a standard graph, but once you get used to that, it becomes quite simple. The CL is the lift coefficient and the CD is the drag coefficient. Using this, we can see that the point of highest lift coefficient is at the top of the graph, and has quite a high drag coefficient too. That must be CLMAX and is therefore the point just before the stall. Before that point is the best lift to drag ratio, where the CL is highest for the lowest CD (dashed line). We can infer from this that the faster speeds are closer to the origin, and the speeds get slower as the graph continues. We can therefore imagine what each of the options would do to the graph, and measure that up with the annex in the question. "Flaps" Flaps increase our CLMAX and also increase drag, so the graph would move up and to the right, which is not the same as the annex. "Landing Gear" Landing Gear won't affect our lift, but they will increase drag, so the graph will move to the right only, not downwards like we see in the annex. "Lift dumpers" Lift dumpers such as wing spoilers reduce lift (as per their name) by ruining the airflow over the wing, and increase drag through this very same method, and by putting an obstruction in the airflow. They would cause the graph to go down and to the right, which matches up with the annex. "Slats" Slats allow an increase in the CLMAX as they allow for higher angles of attack to be flown, but they do not increase drag by very much, so the graph would move upwards, with perhaps a slight movement to the right near the top.

content.question: By lowering the trailing edge flaps...

options.A: wing tip vortex increase due to CP closer to wing root.
options.B: wing tip vortex increase due to CP closer to wing tip.
options.C: wing tip vortex decrease due to CP closer to wing root.
options.D: wing tip vortex decrease due to CP closer to wing tip.

key_points: INDUCED DRAG Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips
The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centre-line of the aircraft
It is the production of lift itself which reduces the magnitude of the lift force being generated
learning.explanation: INDUCED DRAG Whenever a wing produces lift, concentrated vortices form at the wing tips. The vortices are strongest at the wing tips and become progressively weaker toward the centre-line of the aircraft. It is the production of lift itself which reduces the magnitude of the lift force being generated. To replace the lift lost by the increased downwash, the aircraft must be flown at a higher angle of attack. This increases drag. This extra drag is called induced drag. The stronger the vortices, the greater the induced drag. WING TIP VORTICES vs. FLAPS A stronger pressure differential above and below the wing generates stronger wing tip vortices. This may be achieved by flying at a higher angle of attack (flying a heavier airplane or flying slower). Vortex strength is greatest with aircraft in a “clean” configuration (for a given speed and weight). This is because, with flaps extended the outboard portion of extended flaps offer another opportunity for higher-pressure air below the wing to move up. With flaps extended, the aircraft generates four main vortices, weakening their overall effect. With the flaps retracted, those four vortices become two stronger ones.

content.question:
Considering subsonic incompressible airflow through a Venturi, which statement is correct?
I. The dynamic pressure in the throat is the same as in the undisturbed airflow.
II. The total pressure in the throat is lower than in the undisturbed airflow.

options.A: I is incorrect, II is correct.
options.B: I is correct, II is incorrect.
options.C: I is incorrect, II is incorrect.
options.D: I is correct, II is correct.

key_points: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem)
Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time
The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant
learning.explanation: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem). Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time. The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant. The mass air flow 'm' is the product of the density, the area and the velocity: m = ρ * A * V Continuity equation: m1 = m2 = m3 = ρ1 * A1 * V1 = ρ2 * A2 * V2 = ρ3 * A3 * V3 = constant The continuity equation explains the relationship between velocity and cross-sectional area: The speed is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area. Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem) The total energy of an airstream comes in two forms: potential energy (static pressure) and kinetic energy (dynamic pressure). The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy. Thus, an increase in one form of pressure, must result in a decrease in the other. Dynamic pressure (q) is expressed by: q = 1 / 2 * ρ * V2 Assuming the total pressure to be constant, the static pressure and the dynamic pressure vary inversely: If one increases the other decreases and vice-versa. In Conclusion: With a decrease in section area (from station 1 to station 2), flow speed increases, increasing dynamic pressure. Statement 1 is therefore incorrect. The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy. Statement 2 is therefore incorrect.

key_points: For a fixed wing aircraft, ground effect is the increased lift and decreased drag that the wings generate when they are close to the ground
Upon landing, ground effect can give the effect of floating
The stall speed may be temporarily reduced due to ground effect
learning.explanation: For a fixed wing aircraft, ground effect is the increased lift and decreased drag that the wings generate when they are close to the ground. Upon landing, ground effect can give the effect of floating. The stall speed may be temporarily reduced due to ground effect. Ground effect is effective from the ground to approximately half the aircraft’s wingspan above ground. The effect is caused by the ground interrupting the wingtip vortices, decreasing the downwash angle. Below the airfoil, a higher pressure than if an airfoil travels at higher altitude is created, as the air below the airfoil is trapped in between the wing and the ground. This means that the aircraft needs a lower angle of attack for a certain amount of lift. This results in lower induced drag (decreasing induced angle of attack).

options.C: slat asymmetry causes a large rolling moment, whereas flap asymmetry causes a large yawing moment.

Their main contribution is to increase the maximum lift coefficient, but not increase the lift coefficient at a certein AoA
learning.explanation: Slats are aerodynamic surfaces that extend from the leading edge of the wing during slow flight. Their main purpose us to increase the leading edge camber, which delays separation and in so increases the stall angle and corresponding CLMAX. Their main contribution is to increase the maximum lift coefficient, but not increase the lift coefficient at a certein AoA. The negative influence of extending slats is a slight increase in drag. Therefore we can say that at a certain AoA, slats will not increase lift, but they will increase drag slightly, therefore the only resultant moment will be a yaw. Flaps are aerodynamic surfaces that extended from the trailing edge of the wing. Their main purpose is to increase the camber of the wing to increase the coefficient of lift for a certain AoA. options.B: (1) decrease; (2) remain constant; (3) increase; (4) lighter
options.C: (1) increase; (2) increase; (3) increase; (4) the same
options.D: (1) remain constant; (2) decrease; (3) decrease; (4) lighter

key_points: Note: This question was fed back to us with no correct options so we had to modify some of them
This means that it could look different in the exam, so please be careful when answering

We also require as much feedback from the real exam as possible to try and make this question more accurate, so please do let us know if you see this question, and anything you can remember from it, thank you
learning.explanation: Note: This question was fed back to us with no correct options so we had to modify some of them. This means that it could look different in the exam, so please be careful when answering. We also require as much feedback from the real exam as possible to try and make this question more accurate, so please do let us know if you see this question, and anything you can remember from it, thank you. When an airplane flies at a height equal to or less than the length of its wingspan the efficiency of its wings is considerably improved. A low wing airplane, just before touchdown, experiences around a 50% reduction of its induced drag. This phenomenon is called ground effect. Ground effect occurs because the surface alters the airflow pattern around the wings. Primarily, the surface restricts the formation of the wingtip vortices. When an aircraft enters ground effect during the landing phase of flight, the sudden increase in lift and reduction in drag cause it to experience a floating tendency. The aircraft also tends to pitch nose-down due to the reduction in download on the tail plane. The magnitude of the wing tip vortices, and thus upwash and downwash, also determine the amount of induced drag produced by the wing. The closer the aircraft is to the surface, the greater the reduction in induced drag at any given angle of attack. Aircraft entering ground effect: Downwash/Upwash decreases. The effective angle of attack increases. Increased lift during landing if the angle of attack remains constant. The induced angle of attack decreases. Induced drag decreases. Aircraft leaving ground effect: Downwash/Upwash increases. The effective angle of attack decreases. Decreased lift during take-off if the angle of attack remains constant. (So the AoA increases to maintain lift) The induced angle of attack increases. Induced drag increases. In terms of the forces on the controls, it's a tricky one to answer. The forces will change on the elevators as elevators feel the reduced downwash behind the main wings when in ground effect, giving a pitch down moment, so a pitch-up moment is expected upon leaving the ground effect. However, this is not "lighter" or "heavier" controls. We believe that there is no consistent change, but please let us know if this is marked as incorrect in the exam and we can look into changing this. The learning objectives do not mention this, but they are also quite vague on this matter so do not remove it completely.

content.question: Consider two aircraft, the only difference between the two is that one has larger winglets than the other. In the aircraft with the larger winglets, ground effect is expected to:

options.A: decrease because the winglets reduce overall wing tip vortices.
options.B: increase because the winglets reduce overall wing tip vortices.
options.C: decrease because winglets increase overall Drag.
options.D: increase because winglets increase overall Drag.

key_points: Ground effect is caused by rising warm air off the ground, by a reduction in the amount of downwash behind the wings, and by the tendency of the aircraft not to slow (decreased drag) resulting from the reduction of wing-tip vortices
Winglets are aerodynamically eficient surfaces located at the wing tips
They are designed to reduce induced drag
learning.explanation: Ground effect is caused by rising warm air off the ground, by a reduction in the amount of downwash behind the wings, and by the tendency of the aircraft not to slow (decreased drag) resulting from the reduction of wing-tip vortices. Winglets are aerodynamically eficient surfaces located at the wing tips. They are designed to reduce induced drag. They dispense the span-wise airflow from the upper and lower surfaces at different points, thus preventing the intermixing of these airflows that otherwise would create induced-drag vortices. Winglets reduce the size of the vortices and so ground effect will decrease. Larger winglets are more effective at reducing the size of the vortices.

key_points: Aeroplane drag is divided into two types at low speeds, parasite drag and induced drag

learning.explanation: Aeroplane drag is divided into two types at low speeds, parasite drag and induced drag. Parasite drag increases with the square of the speed, induced drag changes with the inverse square of the speed (highest at low speeds). Together, they create the familiar drag curve of an aircraft. Sometimes, we have to convert that graph again, from drag (thrust required) to something more friendly to propeller aircraft. Propeller aircraft cannot measure thrust output, only power (Power = Thrust x Velocity). This means that it is often useful to change thrust required graphs into power required graphs, by multiplying by speed (TAS) again. The curve looks the same, but if you get to compare them, the power required curve is steeper and a little to the left. This is where it can get a little complicated, as drag graphs are often created with IAS on the X-axis, for easy usage at all altitudes, but Power = Thrust x True Airspeed. This means that for the same thrust required (drag), an increase in altitude causes a higher TAS and therefore a higher power required. There we have it then; the power required curve will look almost the same (There is a slight flat section of figure 2 but it is not important, imagine it looks the same as the others), but for each point on the curve, the TAS will be higher (so the curve moves to the right) and therefore the power required will also be higher (so the graph moves upwards). learning.explanation: EFFECT OF FLAPS ON LANDING/TAKE-OFF RUN AND CLIMB GRADIENT The use of high life devices (Flaps) will have an impact on the take-off and Landing roll and climb gradient. For a given runway length and airplane weight, selecting a greater flap setting will increase the wing’s effective camber and the lift coefficient, which reduces the stalling speed. As a consequence, the take-off speeds are reduced (the same lift will be created at smaller air speed due to greater lift coefficient). This will reduce the take-off run. Flap extension during landings provides several advantages by: producing greater lift and permitting lower landing speed; producing greater drag, permitting a steep descent angle without airspeed increase. => Reducing the length of the landing roll. The down side of the use of flaps is that it generates more parasite drag: We get our best angle of climb and, therefore, our best gradient where there is the biggest gap between the thrust available and thrust required. The parasite drag from the extended flap closes the gap and the climb angle and climb gradient will reduce => go around performance is deteriorated. Hence as soon as we can after take off we accelerate and retract the flap and climb clean.

Considering subsonic incompressible airflow through a Venturi, which statement is correct?

key_points: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem)
Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time
The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant
learning.explanation: To understand the venturi effect, we must first introduce two conditions: The conservation of mass (Continuity Equation) and the Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem). Conservation of Mass (Continuity Equation) The mass of air entering the pipe, in each unit of time, equals the mass of air leaving the pipe, in the same unit of time. The mass flow through the pipe must remain constant. The mass air flow 'm' is the product of the density, the area and the velocity: m= ρ*A*V Continuity equation: m1= m2= m3= ρ1* A1* V1= ρ2* A2* V2= ρ3* A3* V3=constant The continuity equation explains the relationship between velocity and cross-sectional area: The speed is inversely proportional to the cross-sectional area. Conservation of Energy (Bernoulli’s Theorem) The total energy of an airstream comes in two forms: potential energy (static pressure) and kinetic energy (dynamic pressure). The total pressure of the airstream is the sum of the static pressure and the dynamic pressure and must remain constant, according to the law of conservation of energy. Thus, an increase in one form of pressure, must result in a decrease in the other. Dynamic pressure (q) is expressed by: q= 1/2* ρ* V2 Assuming the total pressure to be constant, the static pressure and the dynamic pressure vary inversely: If one increases the other decreases and vice-versa. In Conclusion: With a decrease in section area (from station 1 to station 2), flow speed increases, increasing dynamic pressure. If dynamic pressure increases, static pressure decreases. Statement 1 is therefore incorrect. With a decrease in section area (from station 1 to station 2), flow speed increases, increasing dynamic pressure. Statement 2 is therefore incorrect.

content.question: What locations are the most susceptible to ice build-up during flight?

options.A: Parts of the aircraft that have a small radius, bend sharply, and hence have a higher curvature, such as narrow leading edges of the wings and tail, probes and antennas.
options.B: The windscreens and other cockpit windows.
options.C: Parts of the aircraft that have a large radius, and hence are gently curving, with a lower curvature, such as leading edge of a thick wing, the radome, and the fuselage.
options.D: The radome, all the leading edges, upper wing surfaces, and the fuselage.

key_points: The formation of ice and frost on the airframe will: - modify the profile of the aerofoil
- increase the roughness of the aircraft surface
- increase the weight of the aircraft
learning.explanation: The formation of ice and frost on the airframe will: - modify the profile of the aerofoil. - increase the roughness of the aircraft surface. - increase the weight of the aircraft. Ice will normally form on and around the leading edges of wings and tailplane and can result in severe distortion of the leading edge profile. This will give a large increase in drag and a substantial decrease in CLMAX. The skin friction drag will increase and the boundary layer will have an earlier separation, giving a reduced critical angle of attack, thereby a higher stall speed. Ice builds up on an aircraft when the super-cooled water droplets (SCWDs) hit the cold airframe and freeze onto the surface. This will happen most in particular sections of the aircraft, such as the leading edges of the wings, the nose, propeller spinners, the tail leading edges, and any protrusions such as the windshield, pitot tubes, AoA vanes, etc. These are obviously where the air is hitting the aircraft, and therefore some of the SCWDs will hit the airframe. This effect is much more pronounced when the items are sharp, instead of curved. Take a wing for example. When it is a very curved wing, useful for low speed flight, it will have a leading edge with a large radius, and the pressure waves that propagate from the front of the wing during flight are effectively giving the air advanced warning that the wing is coming, so it can move out of the way. This means that the SCWDs also move out of the way, so do not hit the wing as much. This means that sharp wings (with a smaller radius - used for higher speed flight) give less of a "warning" to the air, and the SCWDs will not move out of the way as much, thereby causing more ice accretion. This is the same for sharp protrusions such as the AoA vanes and pitot tubes.

learning.explanation: To determine the efficiency of an aircraft, consider the lift and drag curves together. For maximum efficiency, the wings should produce maximum lift with the least possible drag. The most important point on the lift/drag curve is the angle of attack that gives the best lift/drag ratio, in this case 3 or 4°. This is the most efficient (optimum) angle of attack, at which the airfoil gives its best all round performance (i.e. it produces the most lift for the least amount of drag). At any other angle of attack, the same lift will be obtained at a greater cost in drag.
